examples.en: That treaty will cease to be in effect from tomorrow.
examples.ja: その条約は明日で効力を失う。

examples.en: Your presentation today seemed like it was a bit weaker in its effectiveness compared to the last one.
examples.ja: あなたの今日のプレゼンテーションは、前回に比べて効力が少し弱いような気がしました。

examples.en: If you take this medicine, you will be able to fly in the sky. However, please be careful because if the effect of the medicine wears off while you are flying, it could be very dangerous.
examples.ja: この薬を飲むと、あなたは空を飛べるようになります。でも、飛んでいる時に薬の効力が切れると大変なので、気をつけてくださいね。

examples.en: When a mediation agreement is reached, the mediation report created thereafter holds the same legal effect as a court judgment.
examples.ja: 調停が成立したときに作成される調停調書は、判決と同様の効力を有します。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something's <kanji>effective</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is its <vocabulary>effectiveness</vocabulary>. If it has effective power, it remains <vocabulary>in effect</vocabulary>.

This word usually refers to the legal force or effectiveness of a law, agreement, contract, or treaty, but it can also be used to talk about the efficacy of other things, such as medicine.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is a major project aimed at national reconstruction.
examples.ja: これは国家再建をかけた一大プロジェクトです。

examples.en: To rebuild this building, we will need to secure funding first.
examples.ja: このビルの再建には、まずは資金を作らなくてはいけません。

examples.en: Rebuilding the disaster-stricken areas is top priority now.
examples.ja: 今は被災地の再建が最優先です。

examples.en: He worked longer hours than he was supposed to every day until he rebuilt his struggling company.
examples.ja: 経営が苦しくなった会社を再建するまで、彼は毎日規定よりも長い時間働いた。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Again</kanji> you <kanji>build</kanji> it. This is <vocabulary>rebuilding</vocabulary>.

再建 is a formal word that refers to the act of rebuilding something that has deteriorated or been lost, whether it's a physical structure like a building or an organization, or a part of the body in the context of medical procedures.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!

examples.en: Why do you want to get a position at a company that pays you per diem?
examples.ja: どうして日当で給与を支払う会社に就きたいの？

examples.en: I wonder what kind of jobs we all will end up getting.
examples.ja: みんなどんな仕事に就くことになるのかな。

examples.en: This would definitely make Prince Joffrey take the throne.
examples.ja: これでジョフリー王子が王位に就くのは間違いないね。

examples.en: Who do you think will take Tofugu's president position after Koichi?
examples.ja: コウイチの後、誰がトーフグの社長のポジションに就くと思う？

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>get a position</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get a position</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to get a job</vocabulary>.

Note that 就く is used with another word that indicates a position or a job, like 王位に就く(becoming a king) or 仕事に就く (finding employment).
reading_mnemonic: If you want <vocabulary>to get a position</vocabulary>, there are <reading>two</reading> (つ) interviews. Just pass the two interviews to get a job!

examples.en: You'll be alright. The sun will rise again.
examples.ja: 大丈夫。日はまた昇るさ。

examples.en: In the distance, we saw a long, thin plume of smoke rising into the sky.
examples.ja: 遠くの方に、細長い煙が空に昇っていくのが見えました。

examples.en: I felt like I was ascending to heaven as I read my college acceptance letter over and over.
examples.ja: 私は天にも昇る気持ちで、大学からの合格通知を何度も読み直した。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ascend</kanji> so the verb vocab version must be <vocabulary>to ascend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>.

昇る is commonly used to talk about things like the sun and the moon rising, or smoke rising from a fire.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but it's pretty easy. How do you read all the other "to climb" words? 登る is one example. 上る is another. They're all <reading>のぼ</reading>る, and so is this. Unlike the other climbing words, though, this suggests there's no effort involved. That's why you're "ascending" and not climbing, because climbing is a bit of work.

examples.en: I've had a bit of a stomachache since this morning.
examples.ja: 朝から、ちょっとお腹が痛いんです。

examples.en: In my forties, I've started to get a potbelly.
examples.ja: 四十代になってお腹がぽっこり出てきた。

examples.en: Since I ate until I was completely full of delicious food today, I feel like I can work hard again starting tomorrow.
examples.ja: 今日はおいしいものをお腹いっぱい食べたから、また明日から仕事がんばれそうだよ。

examples.en: "Supper is ready! Come and get it." "Oh, thank god! I'm starving!"
examples.ja: 「お夕飯の支度ができましたよ！いらっしゃい。」「ああ、よかった！お腹ペコペコだよ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

It's common to see this word written in kanji, but you'll also see it written in hiragana, especially in casual contexts.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is an exception, but it isn't too hard to remember. It's the same as <reading>中</reading> (なか), so if you think about it it makes sense. It's your insides, just like your <vocabulary>belly</vocabulary> is your insides!

examples.en: It makes me so mad. They are in the way of our practice!
examples.ja: 本気で腹立つんだけど。練習のジャマだわ！

examples.en: There's something about the way she talks that makes me angry.
examples.ja: 彼女の話し方には、何か腹立つものがある。

examples.en: While hiding her angry feelings, she pretended to be calm and chose her words carefully.
examples.ja: 腹立つ感情を隠しつつ、彼女は冷静をよそおって言葉を選んだ。

examples.en: It's completely natural to feel angry at someone who doesn't keep their promises.
examples.ja: 約束を守らない人に腹立つのは、極めて自然なことである。

meaning_mnemonic: What's that feeling when your <kanji>belly</kanji> <kanji>stands</kanji> up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means <vocabulary>to get mad</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings are 腹 plus 立つ put together. The たつ becomes だつ as a standard reading though.

While はらだつ is the standard reading for 腹立つ, it's usually found in more formal settings or writing. You'll probably hear はらたつ more often in everyday conversations, as it’s a shorter, more colloquial way of expressing 腹が立つ!

examples.en: The feudal lord ordered the low-grade samurai to perform ritual suicide.
examples.ja: 大名はその下級武士に腹切りを命じた。

examples.en: The word "harakiri" might have spread more among foreigners because the sound of it has a strong impact.
examples.ja: 外国人に「腹切り」という言葉の方が広まったのは、響きにインパクトあったからかもね。

examples.en: The word harakiri feels somehow more visceral than seppuku, doesn’t it?
examples.ja: 腹切りって言葉、なんだか切腹よりも生々しい感じがするよね。

examples.en: The movie based on samurai harakiri will be released next week.
examples.ja: 侍の腹切りをテーマにした映画は来週公開されます。

meaning_mnemonic:
If your <kanji>abdomen</kanji> is getting <kanji>cut</kanji>, and you're the one doing the cutting, there's a good chance you're committing <vocabulary>harakiri</vocabulary>, a form of <vocabulary>ritual suicide</vocabulary>.

腹切り sounds blunt and colloquial compared to the more formal 切腹. Kind of like you're just saying the words "belly cutting" — not very refined! This is often the case with synonym pairs like this: the one with kun'yomi readings will sound more casual, while the one with on'yomi readings will sound more formal.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 腹 and 切る. If you're lucky, you already know the word harakiri as it's made its way into English as well.

examples.en: I find it difficult to ask friends to hang out.
examples.ja: 私、友達を誘うのが苦手なんです。

examples.en: I was enticed by the pleasant weather and went for a walk.
examples.ja: 陽気に誘われ、ウォーキングに出かけた。

examples.en: What should we do? Should we also invite Saori to karaoke?
examples.ja: どうする？サオリもカラオケに誘う？

examples.en: If my boss asks me to go eat ramen, I have no choice but to go, right?
examples.ja: 上司にラーメンを食べに行かないかと誘われたら、行くしかないっしょ。

examples.en: I finally asked Sayako out on a date and she said yes, so we're going out for dinner tonight.
examples.ja: ついにサヤコをデートに誘ったんだけど、なんとOKの返事をもらえたんだよ。だから、今夜、食事をしに出かけるんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>invite</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary>.

誘う refers to casually inviting someone to a place, an event, or an activity. If it's an invitation to something tempting, it can also mean <vocabulary>to tempt</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to entice</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everyone is excited to <vocabulary>invite</vocabulary> you to their home for a demo because you've just invented <reading>saw</reading> <reading>so</reading>ap (さそ). What's saw soap? It's a soap that cuts through all the grime!

examples.en: This is my colleague, Hayashi-san.
examples.ja: こちらは同僚の林さんです。

examples.en: My colleague is a cold-hearted man.
examples.ja: オレの同僚は冷たいヤツなんだよ。

examples.en: It would have been nice to have a boss or colleagues to turn to for advice when there was trouble.
examples.ja: 困ったときに相談できるような上司や同僚だったら良かったんだけどね。

meaning_mnemonic:
We work at the <kanji>same</kanji> place and are <kanji>colleague</kanji>s, making us <vocabulary>colleague</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>coworker</vocabulary>s.

As you might guess from the 同 kanji, 同僚 generally refers to people working in the same workplace with the same rank or status. In other words, you wouldn't usually call your boss your 同僚!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He comes from a bureaucratic background, but he's humble and a good guy.
examples.ja: 彼は官僚出身だけど、腰が低くていいやつだよ。

examples.en: I'm sure they all think something like, "It's our rightful privilege as career bureaucrats to secure cushy post-retirement jobs."
examples.ja: きっとアイツらみんな、我々キャリア官僚が天下りするのは当然の権利だとか思ってるんじゃない？

examples.en: Just as bureaucratism inevitably spreads in a large nation, every large organization ends up suffering from what we call "big company syndrome." It's what you might refer to as a bureaucratic organization.
examples.ja: 大きくなった国家に必ず官僚主義がはびこるように、大きくなった組織は、みんな大企業病にかかるんです。いわゆる官僚組織ってやつですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>government</kanji> <kanji>colleague</kanji> is someone who works for the <vocabulary>bureaucracy</vocabulary>, making them a <vocabulary>bureaucrat</vocabulary>.

Just like the word bureaucracy in English, 官僚 often carries a negative connotation, suggesting red tape, inefficiency, or the power and influence that senior civil servants might wield within the government.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Could you explain the process of how you came to that diagnosis?
examples.ja: どうしてその診断結果になったのか、診断のプロセスを説明してもらえませんか？

examples.en: Do you know the personality test called MBTI assessment?
examples.ja: MBTI診断っていう性格診断テスト、知ってる？

examples.en: Doctor Nishimura is believed to be the best doctor in terms of their diagnosis of breast cancer.
examples.ja: 西村医師は乳がんの診断においては右に出る者はいないと言われています。

examples.en: My son was diagnosed with asthma when he was four.
examples.ja: 私の息子は四歳の時に喘息だと診断されました。

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>diagnose</kanji> is to (metaphorically) <kanji>cut off</kanji> all the possibilities you don't believe to be likely. That's how you get a <vocabulary>diagnosis</vocabulary>!

診断 is primarily used in medical contexts to mean the act of <vocabulary>diagnosing</vocabulary> or the diagnosis itself. In non-medical contexts, it can also mean an <vocabulary>assessment</vocabulary> used to evaluate something, like a 性格診断 (personality test).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Our laundry hasn't dried yet.
examples.ja: 洗濯物はまだ乾いていません。

examples.en: The soil in the planter was getting dry, so I gave it some water.
examples.ja: プランターの土が乾いてきたので水をやりました。

examples.en: "Looks like I got shot in the leg three times," Viet said in a dry voice.
examples.ja: 「足を三発撃たれたみたいだ」と、ビエトは乾いた声で言った。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji>, so this verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to get dry</vocabulary>. You're not doing the drying here — it's happening on its own. To remember this, just think about how <reading>coo</reading>l (く) it is that something can become dry all by itself. It's just, like, the magic of nature — how cool is that?
reading_mnemonic: The <reading>川</reading> (かわ) has started <vocabulary>to get dry</vocabulary>. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.

examples.en: Currently it's the height of the dry season here.
examples.ja: ここは今、乾季の真っ最中です。

examples.en: I recommend going during the dry season if you are planning to travel to the Philippines.
examples.ja: フィリピンに旅行に行くなら乾季がオススメですよ。

examples.en: In this region, the dry season lasts from May to October.
examples.ja: この地域では、乾季が5月から10月まで続きます。

examples.en: By now it's usually the dry season already, but it still continues to rain this year.
examples.ja: いつもはこの時期は既に乾季になっているが、今年は未だ雨が降り続けている。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>dry</kanji> <kanji>seasons</kanji> is the <vocabulary>dry season</vocabulary>.

乾季 is a formal term typically used in geographical climate discussions, especially for regions with clear wet and dry seasons like Southeast Asia, Africa, and South America.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's all toast together!
examples.ja: みんなで乾杯しましょう！

examples.en: Cheers to our first reunion after three years!
examples.ja: 三年ぶりの再会に、乾杯！

examples.en: I'll be a bit late, so please kanpai without me and start the party.
examples.ja: 少しおくれるので、先に乾杯して始めてください。

examples.en: Alright, cheers cheers! Hey, bottoms up!
examples.ja: さあ、乾杯、乾杯！それ、ぐいと一杯、飲み干したまえ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>dry</kanji> out your <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> after saying <vocabulary>Kanpai</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>cheers</vocabulary>!

乾杯 means <vocabulary>toast</vocabulary>ing with your drink and is how you say "Cheers!" in Japanese. It literally means "dry your cup" (drink up), so traditionally, people would finish their drink after saying it. But it's much more relaxed nowadays—most people just take a sip for 乾杯.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for the はい turning into ぱい!

examples.en: The teacher encouraged the students to ask more questions.
examples.ja: 先生は生徒にもっと質問をするよう促した。

examples.en: It seems that the news prompted people to take action.
examples.ja: そのニュースが人々に行動を促すきっかけとなったようです。

examples.en: The doctor urged me to quit smoking, but I struggled to follow through.
examples.ja: 医者は禁煙を促されたが、なかなか実行に移せなかった。

examples.en: This campaign aims to promote eco-friendly actions.
examples.ja: このキャンペーンは、環境に優しい行動を促すことを目的としています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>urge</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.

促す means <vocabulary>to encourage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to prompt</vocabulary> someone to take action or proceed with something. Depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to promote</vocabulary> the growth, development, or change of something.
reading_mnemonic: Someone with a weird accent is trying <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary> you to eat "<reading>Unagah</reading>" (うなが). This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.

examples.en: It's been a week and I still haven't received a call, so I plan to send a follow-up email.
examples.ja: 一週間経っても電話がかかってこないから、催促のメールを入れるつもりです。

examples.en: Kaneko-san urged me to return the money, but I don't remember borrowing any.
examples.ja: 金子さんにお金を返してくれと催促されましたが、借りた覚えがありません。

examples.en: My cat’s face when demanding food is just too cute—take a look!
examples.ja: うちのネコがご飯を催促してくるときの顔が可愛すぎるんで、見てください。

examples.en: How can I press a customer to take action on his overdue payment politely but also strongly?
examples.ja: どうすれば顧客に未払分の支払手続きを丁寧かつ強く催促することができるのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: I'm so for this I'm willing to <kanji>sponsor</kanji> you. I am going to <kanji>urge</kanji> you to do this until you do it, so much so I'll give you money. This is one great <vocabulary>urge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>press for</vocabulary> you to do this!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I've finally received the final notification.
examples.ja: ついに、最終催告を送り付けられてしまいました。

examples.en: Since I could not respond to the payment notification, my credit card got suspended.
examples.ja: 催告に応じることが出来ず、クレジットカードが止められてしまった。

examples.en: I received a demand notice because I couldn't pay the mortgage.
examples.ja: 住宅ローンが払えなかったため、催告書がきてしまいました。

examples.en: A consumer credit company has been sending me notification letters over and over, demanding that I pay back my debt.
examples.ja: サラ金から、借金の返済を求める催告状が何度も何度も届いています。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>sponsor</kanji> an <kanji>announce</kanji>ment, you're allowing those you're sponsoring to create some kind of <vocabulary>notice</vocabulary> for all those they want to get in contact with.

催告 refers to the act of <vocabulary>officially notifying</vocabulary> someone with a <vocabulary>formal notice</vocabulary>, urging them to take action within a specified time frame. It's a technical term mainly used in legal or business contexts, like reminding someone to fulfill obligations such as payments or contracts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I wonder what a golf tournament hosted by a celebrity is like.
examples.ja: 芸能人主催のゴルフ大会ってどんなのなんだろう？

examples.en: This event is hosted by the local chamber of commerce.
examples.ja: このイベントは、地元の商工会が主催しています。

examples.en: Actually, the host of this concert is a well-known music producer.
examples.ja: 実はこのコンサートの主催は、とある有名な音楽プロデューサーなんです。

examples.en: The racetrack turf symposium was able to happen because of city government sponsorship.
examples.ja: 競馬場の芝についてのシンポジウムが市当局の主催で開かれた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>sponsor</kanji> for an event is the host who's <vocabulary>hosting</vocabulary> (and possibly sponsoring) it. 

主催 is a formal term often used in business, official events, or public gatherings. While it can imply sponsorship, it mainly refers to the act of leading and organizing an event or activity, as well as the person or group hosting it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My child accidentally broke the glass WaniKani ornament.
examples.ja: 子供が、ガラス製のワニカニの置物を壊してしまったんです。

examples.en: I was careful with my choice of words because I didn't want to damage the relationship.
examples.ja: 関係を壊したくなかったので、言葉選びには気をつけました。

examples.en: Continuing an extreme diet may harm your health.
examples.ja: 無理なダイエットを続けると、体を壊す可能性があります。

examples.en: I cooked this blowfish in my own way and it wrecked my stomach.
examples.ja: この河豚を自分なりに料理してみたんですが、お腹を壊してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>break</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for the things you broke of theirs.
reading_mnemonic: The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic <reading>koa</reading>la (こわ). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.

examples.en: Something came out of the completely destroyed building.
examples.ja: 全壊したビルの中から何か出てきました。

examples.en: I had my own house, but it was completely destroyed by the typhoon.
examples.ja: マイホームを持っていたんですが、台風で全壊しちゃったんですよ。

examples.en: Our house was almost totally destroyed by the tornado, but my family is all safe.
examples.ja: トルネードで自宅はほぼ全壊ですが、家族はみんな元気です。

examples.en: Among the houses that suffered from this earthquake, the number of completely destroyed houses was 835.
examples.ja: この地震で被害を受けた家のうち、全壊家屋は全部で835戸だった。

meaning_mnemonic:
When <kanji>all</kanji> of something <kanji>breaks</kanji>, every last bit of it is broken. It's <vocabulary>complete destruction</vocabulary>!!!

全壊 is a formal term used when buildings or structures are completely destroyed by disasters like earthquakes, fires, or accidents. It's often seen in news reports or insurance assessments to describe the <vocabulary>total destruction</vocabulary> of property.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I just saw a news ticker saying "London Bridge collapses due to a terror attack"! Could it be true?
examples.ja: 今、『テロでロンドンブリッジ倒壊』のテロップが流れてきたよ！本当かな？

examples.en: There were reports that Tokyo Tower might collapse due to the impact of the major earthquake.
examples.ja: 大地震の影響で東京タワーが倒壊するかもしれないとの報道があった。

examples.en: The fire-fighting team rescued a girl from the collapsed building.
examples.ja: 消防隊は、倒壊したビルの中から少女を助け出した。

examples.en: My grandparents' house is so old that it could collapse under the weight of the snow.
examples.ja: 私の祖父母の家はとても古いので、雪の重みで倒壊しかねません。

meaning_mnemonic:
When something <kanji>collapse</kanji>s and <kanji>break</kanji>s, it is when a <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary> happens. Something big collapsing or <vocabulary>falling down</vocabulary> will probably result in its <vocabulary>destruction</vocabulary>.

倒壊 is a formal word often found in news or official documents. It's used to describe buildings or structures collapsing, usually from destructive forces like natural disasters or bombings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have three daughters.
examples.ja: 私には娘が三人います。

examples.en: I heard Matsumoto's daughter is going to be a university student this year!
examples.ja: 松本さんのとこの娘さん、今年大学生になるんだって！

examples.en: It's dangerous for young women to be walking around at this time of night, you know?
examples.ja: こんな時間に若い娘さんたちだけで歩いてたら危ないよ？

examples.en: "My daughter is a mermaid." "Whoa! Does that mean you married a fish?"
examples.ja: 「私の娘は人魚なんだ。」「ええっ、それってつまり、あんた魚と結婚したってことか？」

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

娘 primarily means <vocabulary>daughter</vocabulary> but can also refer to a <vocabulary>young woman</vocabulary> (often unmarried). This is because its original form is 産す女 (むすめ), or "a woman who gives birth." Over time, it came to represent both daughters and young women.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Klara is the only daughter of the Sesemann family.
examples.ja: クララはゼーゼマン家の一人娘です。

examples.en: He has an only daughter.
examples.ja: 彼には一人娘がいます。

examples.en: Ms. Hayashi is raising her only daughter by herself.
examples.ja: 林さんは女手ひとつで一人娘を育てています。

meaning_mnemonic: An "alone" (一人) <kanji>daughter</kanji> is a daughter with no other daughter siblings, making her the <vocabulary>only daughter</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are 一人 plus 娘 put together into one, single (daughter) word.

examples.en: He is interested in various religions.
examples.ja: 彼はさまざまな宗教に関心があります。

examples.en: For many people, religion is a part of their daily lives.
examples.ja: 多くの人々にとって、宗教は生活の一部です。

examples.en: Sometimes, I feel like WaniKani seems a bit like a cult.
examples.ja: 時々、ワニカニってカルト宗教みたいだと思うことがあります。

examples.en: She will be the secretary who records the transactions of the world religions meeting.
examples.ja: 彼女が、世界宗教会議の記録を取る書記を務めます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>religion</kanji> <kanji>teach</kanji>ings are what makes up a <vocabulary>religion</vocabulary>. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: People of all denominations got together at the meeting.
examples.ja: その会議には、あらゆる宗派の人々が集いました。

examples.en: There are various sects in Buddhism.
examples.ja: 仏教にはさまざまな宗派があります。

examples.en: Even within Christianity there are many denominations, each with slightly different doctrines.
examples.ja: キリスト教といっても多くの宗派があって、それぞれ教義が少し違うんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>religion</kanji> <kanji>sect</kanji> is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a <vocabulary>sect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>denomination</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In Zen Buddhism, they teach you to empty your mind and focus on the present moment.
examples.ja: 禅宗では、心を無にして今に集中することを教えています。

examples.en: To calm my mind, I went to a Zen temple and tried Zen meditation.
examples.ja: 心を落ち着けるために、禅宗の寺に行って座禅をしてみました。

examples.en: Following the teachings of Zen Buddhism, he tries to live a simple life.
examples.ja: 禅宗の教えに従って、彼はシンプルな生活を心がけています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>zen</kanji> <kanji>religion</kanji> is a part of Buddhism. It is the <vocabulary>Zen sect</vocabulary> of Buddhism, or <vocabulary>Zen Buddhism</vocabulary>.

Practitioners of 禅宗 follow 禅 (Zen) practices like meditation and mindfulness to achieve enlightenment. That's why it's called 禅宗!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm going to be the organizer of the next banquet.
examples.ja: 今度の宴会の幹事をすることになりました。

examples.en: I need to reserve a banquet hall for the year-end party.
examples.ja: 忘年会のための宴会場を予約しなくてはいけません。

examples.en: I joined the dinner party after wrapping up my work.
examples.ja: 仕事の締めくくりをつけてから、宴会に参加しました。

examples.en: Drinking alcohol with someone you don’t like at a dinner party is a much more tedious task than recording the proceedings of a meeting.
examples.ja: 宴会で嫌な奴とお酒を飲むのは、会議で議事録を記録するより退屈な仕事だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>banquet</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing is when you meet together for a <vocabulary>banquet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dinner party</vocabulary>.

宴会 refers to a gathering where people share food and drinks to celebrate something or deepen their social bonds. It's generally not used for casual dinner parties among friends, but rather for formal or semi-formal social events involving a larger group of people, such as farewell parties for colleagues or workplace holiday parties.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The prince was shot dead during the feast.
examples.ja: 王子は、宴の最中に撃たれて死んだ。

examples.en: The banquet this evening is truly fun, isn't it?
examples.ja: こよいの宴は実に楽しいものですな。

examples.en: Alright, it's party time! Everyone, drink up, drink up!
examples.ja: さぁ、宴じゃ宴じゃ！みんな、飲め飲め！

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

宴 is an old-fashioned word for 宴会. It refers to large, festive feasts in traditional settings, often involving lots of sake and the enjoyment of traditional performing arts. You may see it used in literature or in song lyrics to evoke scenes of grand, lavish banquets from ages past.
reading_mnemonic: At a <vocabulary>banquet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>party</vocabulary>, you don't only get food, you also <reading>歌 GE</reading>T (うたげ), which is you getting a song from a singer. After all, entertainment is just as important as the food when you're at a wild <vocabulary>bacchanal</vocabulary> such as this!

examples.en: You shouldn't go on a diet in an unhealthy way.
examples.ja: 不健康なやり方でダイエットをするのはよした方がいい。

examples.en: Now that I've become a parent, I'm thinking of reevaluating my unhealthy lifestyle.
examples.ja: 私も親になったから、これまでの不健康な生活を見直そうと思ってるんです。

examples.en: This show is violent and contains a lot of unwholesome content, so I don't want my kids watching it.
examples.ja: この番組は暴力的で、不健康な内容が多いので子供には見せたくないんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: If 健康 is "health," then something that is <kanji>not</kanji> this is <vocabulary>unhealthy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 健康 first.

examples.en: The president's joke helped ease the tension.
examples.ja: 社長のジョークに緊張の糸がほぐれました。

examples.en: My hands wouldn't stop sweating from nervousness during the interview.
examples.ja: 面接のときは、緊張で手汗が止まりませんでした。

examples.en: Amidst the palpable tension in the room, she quietly stood up.
examples.ja: 緊張感がただよう会場の中、彼女は静かに立ち上がった。

examples.en: "I have a job interview tomorrow. I'm a little nervous." "Oh, really? Well, I'm sure you'll do fine."
examples.ja: 「明日、就職の面接があるんで、ちょっと緊張してるんだよね。」「え〜そうなの？うまくいくといいね。」

examples.en: I've been having trouble sleeping lately due to stress and tension from work.
examples.ja: 仕事から来るストレスと緊張で、最近よく眠れないんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>tense</kanji> body begins to <kanji>stretch</kanji> tighter and tighter as <vocabulary>nervousness</vocabulary> takes over.

緊張 describes that nervousness you feel before a big event or during a stressful moment. It can also refer to other things that feel tight or strained, like muscle <vocabulary>tension</vocabulary>, or even global tensions and strained relations between countries.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My wrath will not go on for more than three minutes.
examples.ja: 私の怒りは三分以上続かない。

examples.en: Naoko felt intense anger at Kazuki's words.
examples.ja: 直子は和希の言葉にとてつもない怒りを覚えた。

examples.en: Anger often bubbles up slowly after the fact, doesn't it?
examples.ja: 怒りって、後からフツフツわいてくることが多いよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word looks a lot like 怒る, doesn't it? But this word isn't a verb, so you can think of it as referring to <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wrath</vocabulary> itself.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I have a lot of <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> because <reading>I ca</reading>rry (いか) all of my own things (books, luggage, drinks) and no one will ever carry them for me. Plus, the more things I carry, the more anger I carry inside. Ahh!

examples.en: Walking down a dark road is a bit scary.
examples.ja: 暗い道を歩くのはちょっと怖いな。

examples.en: I'm not good with dogs, and I get scared when they come near.
examples.ja: 犬が苦手で、近づかれると怖いんです。

examples.en: That movie was so scary! I couldn't sleep alone at night.
examples.ja: あの映画、本当に怖かった！夜、一人で眠れなかったよ。

examples.en: It seems that a magnitude 7 earthquake occurred on Mars. Scary!
examples.ja: 火星でマグニチュード7の地震が起きたんだってさ。怖いね！

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>scary</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>.

怖い is commonly used in everyday language to describe something that's scary on a more immediate or personal level.
reading_mnemonic: You know what's really <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your <reading>cowo</reading>rkers (こわ). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.

examples.en: She was unable to say anything out of sheer terror.
examples.ja: 彼女は恐怖のあまり、何も言えなくなった。

examples.en: Oh, Minami-senpai, when you suddenly called out to me, I was filled with nothing but fear.
examples.ja: いやー南先輩、先輩に突然呼び出されたときは、恐怖でしかなかったですよ。

examples.en: I'm afraid of heights, so when I went up the CN Tower, my legs froze with fear.
examples.ja: 高い場所が苦手なので、CNタワーに上った時は、恐怖で足がすくみました。

examples.en: When a yakuza told me that the change I gave him was 100 yen short, I felt an incredible amount of fear.
examples.ja: ヤクザにお釣りが百円足りないと言われた時に、とてつもない恐怖を感じました。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>fear</kanji> it. It is <kanji>scary</kanji>. It is pure <vocabulary>terror</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My dad and I are both afraid of heights.
examples.ja: 私も父も高所恐怖症です。

examples.en: I'm claustrophobic, so I have difficulty taking elevators.
examples.ja: 閉所恐怖症のため、エレベーターに乗るのが苦手です。

examples.en: Because of the power harassment I experienced from my boss, I've developed social anxiety.
examples.ja: 上司からパワハラを受けたせいで、対人恐怖症になってしまいました。

examples.en: I studied kanji on WaniKani too much, and while it was great that I learned kanji, I ended up developing a phobia of alligators and crabs.
examples.ja: ワニカニのやり過ぎで漢字を覚えたのはいいけれど、ワニとカニ恐怖症になってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned 恐怖 means "terror," and 〜症 can mean "disease." So what's a terror disease? Well, it's a <vocabulary>phobia</vocabulary>.

In Japanese, 恐怖症 is mostly used as a suffix for specific phobia names, like 高所恐怖症 (acrophobia, or fear of heights). Do you have any 恐怖症?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Have you ever had the experience of waking up in the middle of the night after a terrifying dream?
examples.ja: 恐ろしい夢を見て、真夜中に目が覚めた経験はありませんか？

examples.en: I've never seen Viet with such a terrifying look in his eyes.
examples.ja: あんなに恐ろしい目をしたビエトは見たことがありません。

examples.en: We must never forget the terrors of war.
examples.ja: 我々は、戦争の恐ろしさを忘れてはいけません。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fear</kanji>? When you really feel fear, you think something is <vocabulary>terrifying</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>frightening</vocabulary> or even <vocabulary>dreadful</vocabulary>.

恐ろしい can describe something that inspires deep fear or awe, often beyond normal feelings of fear. Since it can be used to create a dramatic or intense atmosphere, you might find 恐ろしい more often in literature.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

How <vocabulary>terrifying</vocabulary> is it? It's <reading>Oh so</reading> (おそ) terrifying!

examples.en: "Let’s go for a drink." "Sounds like a plan."
examples.ja: 「ちょっと一杯飲みに行かない？」「いいね。」

examples.en: When I was a child, I watched a movie called "One Cup of Soba Noodles in Broth" just once.
examples.ja: 子供の時に「一杯のかけそば」という映画を一度だけ観たことがあります。

examples.en: My mind was so full of the following year's budget that I didn't feel like having even one drink that night.
examples.ja: 次年度の予算のことで頭が一杯な状態だったので、その夜は一杯もお酒を飲む気にはなれなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> is equal to <vocabulary>one cup</vocabulary>. It could just be <vocabulary>a drink</vocabulary>, but if you're measuring exactly one cup, it needs to be <vocabulary>full</vocabulary> to the brim. That's <vocabulary>a lot</vocabulary> of liquid—so be careful not to spill!

一杯 mainly refers to the amount that fills a container, like a cup, glass, bowl, or even spoon. It can also describe something being "full," such as a full stomach or a theater at capacity (like how a cup is filled to the brim!). Depending on the context, it can also mean "a lot," as fullness implies abundance. When it uses that meaning, you'll also often see it written in just kana (いっぱい).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 一 becomes いっ, and 杯 becomes ぱい.

examples.en: I had two glasses of cold lemonade at the beach.
examples.ja: 浜辺で冷たいレモネードを二杯飲んだ。

examples.en: Mixing two teaspoons of olive oil into this sauce will make it smoother.
examples.ja: このソースに小さじ二杯のオリーブオイルを混ぜると、まろやかになります。

examples.en: I ate two bowls of ramen, and now I'm stuffed.
examples.ja: ラーメンを二杯も食べてしまって、お腹がいっぱいです。

examples.en: I had two cups of coffee while the railroad operation was suspended.
examples.ja: 電車が運行を見合わせている間に、コーヒーを二杯飲みました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>cups of liquid</kanji> is equals to <vocabulary>two cups</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>two drinks</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>two glasses</vocabulary>, depending on what your drink is in!

〜杯 is a counter used to count the amount that fills a container, such as a cup, glass, bowl, or even a spoon! The contents don't have to be liquid—you can use 二杯 for two bowls of rice or two spoons of sugar as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Now, add three tablespoons of honey here.
examples.ja: ここで、大さじ三杯のハチミツを入れます。

examples.en: The cream of corn soup at this restaurant was so delicious that I ended up having three bowls.
examples.ja: この店のコーンポタージュが美味しすぎて、三杯も飲んでしまった。

examples.en: I have a habit of drinking three cups of coffee a day—do you think that's caffeine addiction?
examples.ja: 私、一日にコーヒーを三杯飲むのが習慣になってるんですが、これってカフェイン中毒だと思いますか？

examples.en: I was depressed at the time, so I chugged three glasses of beer.
examples.ja: その時ちょっとへこみ気味だったもんで、ビールを三杯一気飲みしちゃったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>cups of liquid</kanji> is equals to <vocabulary>three cups</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>three drinks</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>three glasses</vocabulary> depending on what your drink is in!

〜杯 is a counter used to count the amount that fills a container, such as a cup, glass, bowl, or even a spoon! The contents don't have to be liquid—you can use 三杯 for three bowls of rice or three spoons of sugar as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for 杯, which becomes ばい thanks to our old friend rendaku.

examples.en: I cut a wooden plank with a saw.
examples.ja: ノコギリで木の板を切りました。

examples.en: What are you going to use this plastic board for?
examples.ja: このプラスチックの板、何に使うの？

examples.en: I'm looking for a marble board that matches this ornament.
examples.ja: この置物に合う大理石の板をさがしています。

examples.en: I posted some comments on a forum about baseball on 2chan, but I was told it was the wrong board.
examples.ja: 2chの野球板に書き込みをしたんですが、板違いだと言われてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

板 generally refers to something thin, flat, and solid, like a board, plank, slab, or plate. In some contexts, it can also refer to stock market boards that display trading prices, or bulletin boards used for posting messages in online forums.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who can make good use of various <vocabulary>board</vocabulary>s? An avid <reading>eater</reading> (いた)! If you’re an avid eater, you’ll need lots of (cutting) boards to prepare all the delicious food you’re going to eat. This makes boards and eaters the perfect match.

examples.en: The signboard of this restaurant is big and very eye-catching.
examples.ja: このレストランの看板は大きくてよく目立ちます。

examples.en: The billboard was blown away by the typhoon.
examples.ja: 台風で看板が飛ばされてしまいました。

examples.en: She is the face of this store.
examples.ja: 彼女はこの店の看板です。

examples.en: There is a dent in the store sign because some drunk guy punched it.
examples.ja: 酔っぱらいの男が殴ったせいで、お店の看板がへこんでいるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>watch over</kanji> <kanji>board</kanji> is a board that's put up and watches over everything. What kind of board watches over everything from up high? One that gets the most visibility, so probably a <vocabulary>signboard</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>billboard</vocabulary>.

看板 typically refers to physical signs, such as <vocabulary>store sign</vocabulary>s or billboards. But it can also mean the figurative symbol or face of a business, like 看板メニュー (signature dish) or 看板娘 (popular female employee).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meanings: To Get To The Bottom Of

examples.en: It is difficult to identify the best time to buy stocks.
examples.ja: 株の買い時を見極めるのは難しい。

examples.en: I want to see the truth with my own eyes.
examples.ja: 自分のこの目で真実を見極めたいんです。

examples.en: To truly assess his abilities, you should give him more tasks to handle.
examples.ja: 彼の能力を見極めるには、もっと仕事を任せてみるべきだ。

examples.en: Koichi can identify whether a dictionary has a good or bad index just by looking at its cover.
examples.ja: コウイチは、辞書の表紙を見ただけで、その辞書の索引が良い索引か悪い索引かを見極めることができる。

meaning_mnemonic:
極める is "to carry to extremes." If you take the action of <kanji>see</kanji>ing something to the extremes, you're going <vocabulary>to get to the bottom of</vocabulary> whatever it is. You'll be able <vocabulary>to identify something</vocabulary>, like the truth.

見極める primarily involves the careful examination and discernment of the underlying aspects or truth of a matter. It emphasizes the thoroughness and effort required to make well-informed decisions or judgments, particularly when the situation is complex or difficult to understand.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words 見る and 極める put together. Get to the bottom of this word and learn it.

examples.en: This issue is extremely important.
examples.ja: この問題は極めて重要です。

examples.en: This medicine has extremely few side effects.
examples.ja: この薬は副作用が極めて少ないです。

examples.en: We are facing an extremely dangerous situation.
examples.ja: 我々は、極めて危険な状況に直面しています。

examples.en: It’s extremely obvious that you don’t have any idea how we can solve this problem.
examples.ja: 君がこの問題の解決方法について具体的には何も考えていないというのは、極めて明白な事実だ。

meaning_mnemonic: 極める is "to carry to extremes." So, 極めて is something similar. It's used to refer to something that's <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary> _______.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 極める.

examples.en: Japanese food is popular even in the West.
examples.ja: 日本の食べ物は欧米でも人気があります。

examples.en: The hotel's main customers are Westerners.
examples.ja: このホテルの主なお客様は、欧米の方々なんです。

examples.en: Can you name all the countries included in "Europe and the US"?
examples.ja: 「欧米」に含まれる国を全部挙げることができますか。

examples.en: I'm searching for a place in Europe and America that grows pink roses.
examples.ja: 欧米でピンクのバラを栽培している所がないか探しているんですが。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>Europe</kanji> and <kanji>America</kanji>. This word refers to <vocabulary>Europe and America</vocabulary>. 

When people use 欧米 in Japan, they usually mean Western countries in general (<vocabulary>the West</vocabulary>), including North America and Western Europe. You'll often see it in news reports related to Western countries or in topics comparing Japanese and Western cultures, customs, or trends.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Among Central European countries, I would like to visit the Czech Republic.
examples.ja: 中欧の国だったら、チェコに行ってみたいです。

examples.en: I had been thinking that Germany was a part of Western Europe, but it was actually one of the Central European countries, wasn't it?
examples.ja: ドイツは西欧だと思っていたんですが、中欧の国の一つだったんですね。

examples.en: This summer, I took a solo trip through Central Europe.
examples.ja: この夏は、中欧をひとり旅してきました。

examples.en: I’ve wanted to travel around Central Europe for a really long time.
examples.ja: 中欧を旅してみたいなと随分長い間思っていたんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> part of <kanji>Europe</kanji> is <vocabulary>Central Europe</vocabulary>, wherever that is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Mizuno-san goes back and forth from Japan to Europe a lot for her work.
examples.ja: 水野さんは仕事で日欧を行き来することが多い。

examples.en: Since there's a time difference between Japan and Europe, it's hard to coordinate meetings.
examples.ja: 日欧間の時差があるので、会議の時間を調整するのが大変です。

examples.en: The Japan-Europe cultural exchange festival will be held next month.
examples.ja: 来月、日欧文化交流フェスティバルが開催されます。

examples.en: The meeting concerning trade between Europe and Japan was sidetracked due to the moderator’s absence.
examples.ja: 日欧貿易に関する会議は、司会者の不在によって横道に逸れてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The 日 refers to "Japan" (It's the 日 of 日本). So, you have Japan and <kanji>Europe</kanji>, which makes this <vocabulary>Japan and Europe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese-European</vocabulary>.

日欧 is a fairly formal word commonly found in newspapers or official reports, where it’s often used for brevity when referring to Japan and Europe together, like in 日欧関係 (Japanese-European relations).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The Edo period lasted for about 260 years.
examples.ja: 江戸時代は約260年間続きました。

examples.en: Please tell me the characteristics of Edo-style sushi.
examples.ja: 江戸前ずしの特徴を教えてください。

examples.en: The diorama that replicates the townscape of Edo is a highlight of this museum.
examples.ja: この博物館では江戸の町並みを再現したジオラマが見ものです。

examples.en: Stop mucking around and go upstairs and do your homework. You said you gotta write an essay about the Edo period in Japan, right?
examples.ja: だらだらしてないで、さっさと二階に行って宿題をしなさい。日本の江戸時代についてレポートを書かないといけないって言ってたでしょ！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>bay</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> isn't what you might think, it refers to <vocabulary>Edo</vocabulary>, which is what Tokyo was called back in the day. You'll still see references to it everywhere, though, so it's good to learn. You can also call this <vocabulary>Tokyo</vocabulary> if you want, but I'd prefer if you answered "Edo," instead.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just watch out for that rendaku on 戸, which changes the reading to ど. Of course, it will be easy if you already know the word <vocabulary>Edo</vocabulary>!

examples.en: We swam in a quiet cove.
examples.ja: 静かな入り江で泳ぎました。

examples.en: Mr. Irie told me that dolphins often visit this cove.
examples.ja: この入り江にはイルカがよくあそびに来ると入江さんが言っていた。

examples.en: I was proposed to by someone I didn’t know in a cove north of the Baltic Sea. It was so romantic that I couldn't help accepting.
examples.ja: バルト海の北の入り江で知らない人からプロポーズされたんですが、とてもロマンチックだったのでつい承諾してしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>enter</kanji> an <kanji>inlet</kanji>, you've gone into the <vocabulary>inlet</vocabulary>. It's also where water goes inside of the inlet (it's entering the inlet from the ocean, or whatever), so that's another way to think about it.
reading_mnemonic: For this reading, just imagine this as 入り with 江 pushed on at the end! Also note this is commonly written as 入江, but the reading stays the same!

examples.en: Garnishing ice cream with a mint leaf gives it a bit of a stylish touch.
examples.ja: アイスクリームにミントの葉っぱを添えると、少しオシャレな感じになりますよ。

examples.en: I gave the present with a message card attached.
examples.ja: プレゼントにメッセージカードを添えて渡しました。

examples.en: What do you think about a man who puts his hand on your waist even though you're not in a relationship?
examples.ja: 付き合ってもないのに、腰に手を添えてくる男性ってどう思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. When <kanji>append</kanji>ing something, you basically want <vocabulary>to add something to</vocabulary> something, or <vocabulary>to include something</vocabulary> with it. 

添える means to add something alongside the main thing, often as a thoughtful touch to complement or support it. For example, you might say 添える when including a letter with a gift to add a personal touch, or when garnishing a dish with parsley to enhance its appearance. It's also used when you feel inclined to add a second hand to hold a bowl carefully.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One way <vocabulary>to add something to</vocabulary> something else is to just <reading>sew</reading> (そ) it on!

examples.en: As for Koichi's plans, please check the attached schedule.
examples.ja: コウイチの予定につきましては、添付のスケジュールをご確認ください。

examples.en: WaniKani emails often have funny GIFs attached.
examples.ja: WaniKaniのメールには、よく面白いGIFが添付されています。

examples.en: Where is the list of the necessary attached documents for a green card application?
examples.ja: グリーンカード申請に必要な添付書類のリストはどこにありますか。

examples.en: Dear hiring manager, please have a look at the resume attached to this email. Thank you for your time.
examples.ja: 人事部長様、 恐れ入りますが、このEメールに添付された履歴書にお目通し頂けますでしょうか。お忙しいとは存じますが、よろしくお願い申し上げます。

meaning_mnemonic: Append and attach this document to your email. That’s called attachment. 添付 refers to the act of attaching something supplementary to another document, like attaching a file to an email or attaching a map to an invitation.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 添 is what you'd expect. The reading for 付 is the on'yomi reading ふ, which you've learned with 付近. But for this word it becomes ぷ from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an <vocabulary>attachment</vocabulary> where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of <reading>poo</reading>p (ぷ). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.

examples.en: My first impression of Miyazaki-san when we met was very striking.
examples.ja: 初めて会った時の宮崎さんの印象は、とても強烈でした。

examples.en: The midsummer sun in Japan was so intense that it stung and felt painful.
examples.ja: 真夏の日本の日差しは強烈で、ヒリヒリして痛いくらいでした。

examples.en: His shocking remark instantly froze the atmosphere in the room.
examples.ja: 彼の強烈な発言で、会場の空気が一気に凍りつきました。

examples.en: I had a cigarette for the first time in ages, and I got hit hard with a nicotine buzz.
examples.ja: ひっさびさにタバコ吸ったら、強烈なヤニクラくらっちまったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that are <kanji>strong</kanji> and <kanji>intense</kanji> are <vocabulary>very strong</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intense</vocabulary>.

強烈 describes something so strong or intense that it leaves a lasting impression and is often <vocabulary>shocking</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>striking</vocabulary>. It can refer to vividly bright colors, a blinding flash of light, extreme heat, or unusually bold or impactful comments.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He finished the work at an intense speed.
examples.ja: 彼は猛烈なスピードで仕事を終わらせました。

examples.en: She studied intensely and passed the exam.
examples.ja: 彼女は猛烈に勉強して、試験に合格しました。

examples.en: Yesterday's concert was ferociously fun!
examples.ja: 昨日のライブ、猛烈に楽しかった！

examples.en: I seriously regret that I volunteered to be the leader of this project now.
examples.ja: このプロジェクトのリーダーを買って出たことを、今猛烈に後悔しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you're <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji> then you are <vocabulary>fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>.

猛烈 is used to describe <vocabulary>intense</vocabulary> things, like fierce storms, or actions done with great intensity, like working like mad. Its strong tone can feel a bit comical in casual use, so people also use it playfully to exaggerate things like how hungry they feel.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The venue was filled with passionate fans of the band.
examples.ja: そのバンドの熱烈なファンが会場をいっぱいにしていた。

examples.en: I was moved by his impassioned love letter, and decided to start dating him.
examples.ja: 彼からの熱烈なラブレターに感動して、付き合うことにしたんです。

examples.en: He is a fervent supporter of that author's works.
examples.ja: 彼はその作家の作品を熱烈に支持している。

examples.en: The woman said, "I'm an ardent fan of Tofugu," and gave Koichi a passionate kiss.
examples.ja: その女性は、「トーフグの熱烈なファンなんです」と言って、コウイチに熱烈なキスをした。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>fever</kanji> turns <kanji>violent</kanji> when you express your <vocabulary>fervent</vocabulary> feelings.

熱烈 is a relatively formal word that describes someone being fervently absorbed in something or someone and showing <vocabulary>ardent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>passionate</vocabulary> behavior, like 熱烈に応援する (support fervently).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He studied fiercely and passed the university entrance exam.
examples.ja: 彼は猛勉強して、大学に合格しました。

examples.en: A fierce blizzard piled up about three meters of snow.
examples.ja: 猛ふぶきで雪が三メートル程積もりました。

examples.en: That dog suddenly dashed at me fiercely, and I was shocked!
examples.ja: あの犬、急に猛ダッシュしてきたからびっくりしたよ！

examples.en: The motorcycle came rushing forward at breakneck speed.
examples.ja: バイクが猛スピードで突っ込んできた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can put this on other words to say that it's a "<vocabulary>Fierce</vocabulary> ____" or "<vocabulary>Intense</vocabulary> _____," or something along those lines. If you see this, you know that something is being done really fiercely or intensely.

猛 is used in compounds to emphasize fierceness or intensity, like 猛暑 (intense heat) or 猛勉強 (intense studying). It can also be used in expressions like 猛アプローチ (relentlessly pursuing someone romantically — a fierce "approach"). In casual uses like this, the strong tone is often intentionally goofy or comical.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's stuck onto things making it all jukugo and such.

examples.en: Young Japanese people tend to abbreviate words and phrases.
examples.ja: 日本の若者はすぐ単語やフレーズを略したがる。

examples.en: Please write your full name without abbreviating it.
examples.ja: 略さずにフルネームを書いてください。

examples.en: As an outsider, I have no idea what you are talking about when you speak in abbreviated form.
examples.ja: 略して話されても部外者の私には何のことか全然分かりません。

examples.en: I apologize, but we cannot skip the procedure.
examples.ja: 恐れ入りますが、手続きを略すことはできないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>abbreviation</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to abbreviate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shorten</vocabulary>. In some cases, it can also mean <vocabulary>to omit</vocabulary> something for the sake of simplicity.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. <reading>りゃく</reading>す.

examples.en: In Japanese conversation, it is the default to omit grammatical subjects except when necessary.
examples.ja: 日本語の会話では、必要なとき以外は文法上の主語を省略するのがデフォルトです。

examples.en: This is an important point, so don't omit anything and write everything down.
examples.ja: ここは大切なポイントだから省略しないで全部書くように。

examples.en: It says "Ma" at the expiry date, but I wonder if this is an abbreviation of "March" or "May".
examples.ja: 賞味期限の所に「Ma」って書いてあるんだけど、「March」の省略かな、それとも「May」の省略かな？

examples.en: I have to omit the details for now due to time constraints, but I’ll explain it to you later.
examples.ja: 時間の都合上、今は詳細については省略せざるを得ませんが、また後ほどご説明させて頂きます。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Conserve</kanji> those letters with <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> and now you're <vocabulary>omitting</vocabulary> all the extra fluff! 

省略 is a relatively formal word used when you are intentionally <vocabulary>leaving out</vocabulary> something for the sake of brevity or simplicity, like an unneeded explanation or a long-winded greeting. It can also sometimes refer to the <vocabulary>abbreviation</vocabulary> of a word or phrase.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: "Kōkō" is an abbreviation of "kōtōgakkō (high school)."
examples.ja: 「高校」は「高等学校」の略語です。

examples.en: Takeshita-san loves to speak using creative abbreviations.
examples.ja: 竹下さんはクリエイティブな略語を使って話すのが大好きです。

examples.en: I don't understand the abbreviations that young people use recently. They are too difficult.
examples.ja: 最近の若者が使う略語は、難しすぎてよく分かりません。

examples.en: Can I borrow your dictionary of acronyms and abbreviations?
examples.ja: 略語辞典を貸してもらえませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Abbreviation</kanji> in <kanji>language</kanji> is an <vocabulary>abbreviation</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>acronym</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'll draw a rough map from your house to mine and email it to you.
examples.ja: あなたの家からうちまでの略図をかいて、メールでお送りします

examples.en: Could you show me the rough diagram you made?
examples.ja: あなたが作った略図をちょっと見せてもらえませんか？

examples.en: I feel uneasy with just the rough map, so I'll use GPS as well, just in case.
examples.ja: 略図だけでは不安なので、念のためGPSも使います。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> version of a <kanji>diagram</kanji> doesn't include all the details. It's more like a <vocabulary>rough diagram</vocabulary> that shows only the essentials.

While 略図 can be used for any simplified diagram, it most commonly refers to a <vocabulary>rough map</vocabulary> that gives a basic overview of an area.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Just a rough summary is fine, so can you tell me what the meeting was about?
examples.ja: 大略でいいので、会議の内容を教えてくれませんか？

examples.en: Can you explain the outline of the incident first?
examples.ja: まずは事件の大略を説明してくれないか？

examples.en: I understood the gist of his story, but I'm still unclear on the details.
examples.ja: 彼の話の大略は理解できたけど、細かい部分はまだよく分かりません。

examples.en: The broad outline of this project has been decided, so let's work out the details next.
examples.ja: この企画の大略は決まったので、次は詳細を詰めていきましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the <vocabulary>broad outline</vocabulary> of something bigger.

大略 is a relatively formal word commonly found in writing. It generally refers to a broader, rougher <vocabulary>outline</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>overview</vocabulary> rather than a detailed summary.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There's no pain in particular.
examples.ja: 特に痛みはありません。

examples.en: I hope that my kid will grow up to become an adult who understands others’ pain.
examples.ja: 子供には人の痛みが分かるような大人に育ってほしいです。

examples.en: I have a hard spot and pain in my breast. Should I have it examined for breast cancer?
examples.ja: 胸にしこりみたいなものと痛みがあるんだけど、乳がん検査した方がいいかな？

examples.en: Apparently, my aunt had a sharp pain in her chest while pooping and called 119.
examples.ja: 俺の伯母さん、クソしてる時に胸にするどい痛みが走って、119に電話したんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: 痛い is "painful." This is the noun version, it is <vocabulary>a pain</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pain</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 痛い. No pain here.

examples.en: I had a bad headache, so I took a painkiller.
examples.ja: 頭痛がひどいので、痛み止めを飲みました。

examples.en: The painkiller is starting to take effect, and I feel a bit better.
examples.ja: 痛み止めが効いてきて、少し楽になりました。

examples.en: Could you pick up some painkillers for me from the pharmacy?
examples.ja: 薬局で痛み止めを買ってきてもらえませんか？

examples.en: He took a painkiller and kept plowing the field.
examples.ja: 彼は痛み止めを飲んで、また畑を耕し始めた。

meaning_mnemonic: 痛み is "pain." 止める is "to stop." What stops pain if you use it? How about a <vocabulary>painkiller</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 痛み and 止める put together into one word. Not too painful, right? Just remember the rendaku on the ど.

examples.en: These days, I can't sleep well due to stress.
examples.ja: 最近ストレスでよく眠れないんです。

examples.en: She likes to sleep with the lights on.
examples.ja: 彼女は電気をつけながら眠るのが好きです。

examples.en: Of course, I try to sleep, but it's pretty hard to fall asleep on a plane, don't you think?
examples.ja: もちろん、眠ろうと努力はするけど、飛行機の中ってなかなか眠れないじゃないですか？

examples.en: "Did you sleep well?" "Yeah, I crashed."
examples.ja: 「ぐっすり眠れた？」「ああ。爆睡したよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: 眠い is "sleepy." The verb version of this is to sleep, or to fall asleep. yawn While 寝る can mean lying down or going to bed (not just sleeping), 眠る only refers to falling asleep or being in a state of sleep.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 眠い.

examples.en: Sleeping potions are often featured in fairy tales to make people fall asleep.
examples.ja: 童話には、眠り薬を使って人を眠らせる話がよく出てきます。

examples.en: Oh no! I lost the bottle with the sleeping pills!
examples.ja: 大変！眠り薬が入ったビンを無くしてしまったわ！

examples.en: The man grinned and pulled out the sleeping drugs from his pocket.
examples.ja: 男はニヤリと笑って、ふところから眠り薬を取り出しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Some kind of <kanji>sleep</kanji>ing <kanji>medicine</kanji>? That's a <vocabulary>sleeping potion</vocabulary>!

眠り薬 is often found in storytelling contexts to refer to some kind of sleep-inducing concoction. But it can also be used as a less medical and more colloquial term for actual sleeping medication.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is 眠い plus 薬 put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz
Just remember that くすり turns into ぐすり here because of rendaku.

examples.en: I can't sleep without sleeping pills.
examples.ja: 睡眠薬が無いと眠れないんです。

examples.en: I couldn't sleep last night, so I took a sleeping pill.
examples.ja: 昨夜、眠れなかったので、睡眠薬を飲みました。

examples.en: Sleeping pills can be dangerous if you don't stick to the prescribed amount.
examples.ja: 睡眠薬は決められた量を守って飲まないと危険ですよ。

examples.en: I'm so uncoordinated right now because of the sleeping pill I took a little bit ago.
examples.ja: さっき飲んだ睡眠薬のせいで、手足が思うように動かないんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Drowsy</kanji> <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>medicine</kanji> sounds a little goofy, but it's exactly what you'd expect it to be: <vocabulary>sleeping pills</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleeping medication</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It snows, but it doesn’t usually accumulate much.
examples.ja: 雪はふるんですが、あまり積もることはないです。

examples.en: I plan to clean up all the dust that piled up throughout the year at the end of the year.
examples.ja: 年末に積もりに積もったホコリを全部そうじするつもりです。

examples.en: They say "little by little, dust becomes a mountain," so I'll keep working hard every day!
examples.ja: 「ちりも積もれば山となる」って言うし、毎日コツコツ頑張るよ！

examples.en: The frustration that had built up over the years suddenly overflowed all at once.
examples.ja: 長年積もりに積もった不満が、一気にあふれ出しちゃったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accumulate</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary>.

積もる is used to describe when something continuously collects or piles up over time, like snow on the ground or dust in a room. It can also be used in a more emotional way, like when feelings or thoughts quietly build up inside someone.
reading_mnemonic: If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least <reading>two</reading> (つ) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.

examples.en: Are the methods for calculating the area of a rectangle and a square the same?
examples.ja: 長方形と正方形の面積を求める方法は同じですか。

examples.en: How large of an area is Koichi's yard?
examples.ja: コウイチの家の庭の面積はどれくらいですか？

examples.en: The area of his forehead is 100 square meters.
examples.ja: 彼のおでこの面積は100平方メートルある。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>surface</kanji> that <kanji>accumulate</kanji>s into one area is a particular <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>. This has to do with math. When you add all the surfaces together by accumulating them into one calculation, you get yourself the area!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Find the volume of this cube.
examples.ja: この立方体の体積を求めなさい。

examples.en: The volume of water can change depending on the temperature.
examples.ja: 水の体積は温度によって変わることがあります。

examples.en: The volume of a rectangular prism can be calculated as "length × width × height," and the volume of a cube can be calculated as "side × side × side."
examples.ja: 直方体の体積は、「たて×横×高さ」、立方体の体積は、「１辺×１辺×１辺」で計算できます。

examples.en: My dad told me to measure the volume of our garage, but I don't know why. It seems kind of weird to me.
examples.ja: 父さんにガレージの体積を測るように言われたんだけど、理由は知らないよ。何か変だよね。

meaning_mnemonic: See how much liquid this <kanji>body</kanji> can <kanji>accumulate</kanji> in order to calculate its <vocabulary>volume</vocabulary>. It can be the body of a cup, the body of a bucket, or the body of a body. Whatever it is, the body accumulation represents its volume. (You know, how much space it takes up. Wasn't math class fun?)
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'll look it up on the Internet later.
examples.ja: 後でネットで検索してみるよ。

examples.en: The search engine I use most often is Google.
examples.ja: 私がよく利用する検索エンジンはグーグルです。

examples.en: This book has an index for easy reference.
examples.ja: この本には検索しやすいように索引がついている。

examples.en: I have so many cookbooks, but I end up searching on Cookpad.
examples.ja: こんなにたくさんの料理本を持っているのに、結局クックパッドで検索しちゃうんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>examine</kanji> then <kanji>search</kanji>. These are the steps you take in order to perform a <vocabulary>lookup</vocabulary> of some kind. Or, as the case may be in modern times, do an <vocabulary>internet search</vocabulary>.

検索 originally referred to looking up information in books or using indexes and reference cards, like in a library. These days it's almost always used for digital and online searches.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't know how to look at the index.
examples.ja: 索引の見方が分かりません。

examples.en: Wouldn't it be faster to look it up in the index?
examples.ja: 索引を引いた方が速いんじゃない？

examples.en: All of the terms in the index are listed in alphabetical order.
examples.ja: 索引にはすべての用語がアルファベット順に並んでいます。

examples.en: We should make an English index too.
examples.ja: 英語索引も付けた方がいいんじゃないかな。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>search</kanji> then <kanji>pull</kanji> items from the <vocabulary>index</vocabulary> — you know, that list of keywords in alphabetical order at the end of a nonfiction book. Or in 五十音順 order, if you're fancy enough to be reading Japanese!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just think of the first part of the word <reading>in</reading>dex (いん). Where do you search? In the index.

examples.en: My dad had to undergo emergency surgery.
examples.ja: 父は緊急手術を受けることになりました。

examples.en: An urgent matter came up, so I have to leave immediately.
examples.ja: 緊急の用事ができたので、すぐに帰らなければならなくなってしまいました。

examples.en: We also need you to provide a phone number for an emergency contact who is not a family member.
examples.ja: 緊急連絡先として、家族以外の方の電話番号も書いていただく必要があります。

examples.en: Three seconds after receiving an emergency earthquake report on my cellphone, the earthquake occurred.
examples.ja: 緊急地震速報を携帯で受信した三秒後に、地震が起きました。

meaning_mnemonic: Things are <kanji>tense</kanji> and we have to <kanji>hurry</kanji>! This is quite the <vocabulary>urgent</vocabulary> <vocabulary>emergency</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When is the deadline?
examples.ja: 締切はいつですか？

examples.en: The application deadline is in three days.
examples.ja: 申込の締切日は三日後です。

examples.en: At this rate, I might not make the deadline.
examples.ja: このままじゃ締切に間に合わないかもしれない。

examples.en: Did you have any luck with putting the deadline off till tomorrow?
examples.ja: うまく締切を明日まで延ばせたの？

meaning_mnemonic:
Things 締める (tighten), and eventually 切る (cut off), meaning you’ve reached the <vocabulary>deadline</vocabulary>! You can associate this with the feeling of your chest tightening once you approach the <vocabulary>due date</vocabulary> for something.

Note that you'll often encounter this written with okurigana like 締め切り as well. You might even see it with a simplified version of the 締 kanji written 〆切, which is relatively common in handwriting!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is the stem form of both verbs, so 締め (しめ) and 切り (きり), put together!

examples.en: This seat belt tightens on its own.
examples.ja: このシートベルトは自動的に締まってくれます。

examples.en: Mr Onishi's body is well toned isn't it!
examples.ja: 大西さんの体はよく締まっていますね〜。

examples.en: This is my first managerial position and I’m very tense.
examples.ja: 初めての管理職ということで、身の引き締まる思いをしています。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tighten</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
What can you do if you want something <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become tight</vocabulary>? You need to hug your <reading>shee</reading>p (し) really close until...

The sheep tightens into a tiny little ball. Cute!

examples.en: The minister's statement was widely covered in the news.
examples.ja: 大臣の発言がニュースで大きく取り上げられました。

examples.en: The Finance Minister announced next year's budget plan.
examples.ja: 財務大臣が来年度の予算案を発表しました。

examples.en: With all due respect, Minister, I believe you should listen more carefully to the voices of the people.
examples.ja: お言葉ですが、大臣は、国民の声をもっとしっかりと聞くべきだと思います。

examples.en: She was fired because she forgot to hand out the documents to the cabinet members before the meeting.
examples.ja: 彼女は大臣たちに会議の前に資料を配るのを忘れてしまったために、首になっちゃったんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>servant</kanji> is a really important servant — you know, one who serves a king or some other political leader. What do we call a big, highfalutin servant who prances around doing jobs for the leader? A <vocabulary>minister</vocabulary>.

大臣 refers to high-ranking government officials who oversee ministries or departments, and it can be translated in different ways depending on the country and its political system, such as <vocabulary>cabinet minister</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>state minister</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>secretary of state</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Where did you learn aerial navigation?
examples.ja: どこで空中航法を学んだんですか。

examples.en: My grandmother can do navigational calculations for airships.
examples.ja: 私のおばあちゃんは、飛行船の航法計算ができるんです。

examples.en: I heard that the navigator used to sit in the back of this aircraft to navigate.
examples.ja: この機体の後ろのところに航法士が乗ってナビしてたんだって。

examples.en: Thanks to my knowledge of celestial navigation, I was able to arrive at the port without getting lost.
examples.ja: 天則航法を学んでおいたおかげで迷わずに港に着くことができました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>navigation</kanji> <kanji>method</kanji>s are the methods used for <vocabulary>navigation</vocabulary>.

航法 is a technical term for navigation, specifically referring to the techniques and methods used to guide a ship, aircraft, or spacecraft from one place to another.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I studied aerospace engineering in the Department of Aerospace Engineering at Japan Aviation University.
examples.ja: 私は日本航空大学の航空工学科で、航空工学について学びました。

examples.en: The number of flight routes from America to Haneda Airport increased and has made travel more convenient.
examples.ja: アメリカから羽田空港の航空路線が増えてより便利になりました。

examples.en: I always use this app to search for cheap airline tickets.
examples.ja: 私はいつもこのアプリを使って格安航空券をさがしています。

examples.en: That airline company is adding a new route in April.
examples.ja: あの航空会社は四月に新路線を増やす予定だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Navigation</kanji> in the <kanji>sky</kanji> is <vocabulary>aviation</vocabulary>. Vroom vroom, sky flying!

On its own 航空 refers to aviation, but you'll usually see it in compound words like 航空機 (aircraft) and 航空会社 (airline company).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This ship is on a direct voyage to Kobe Port.
examples.ja: この船は神戸港に直航します。

examples.en: My children are still small, so I would like to take a direct flight if possible.
examples.ja: 子供がまだ小さいのでできれば直航の飛行機で行きたいと思っています。

examples.en: This flight doesn't go directly from Portland to Tokyo; it makes a stop in Alaska along the way.
examples.ja: この便はポートランドから東京まで直航せず、途中でアラスカに寄港します。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 直行 is "nonstop"? Well, with 直航 it's the same thing, but it's only used for flights and boat trips, making this a <vocabulary>nonstop flight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>direct voyage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This shopping street has a lot of small traditional shops.
examples.ja: この商店街には、昔ながらの小さなお店がたくさんあります。

examples.en: This shopping street is popular with tourists and is always bustling.
examples.ja: この商店街は観光客にも人気で、いつもにぎわっています。

examples.en: Traditional shopping streets are rapidly disappearing due to the opening of large stores.
examples.ja: 大型店の出店で、昔ながらの商店街がどんどん姿を消しています。

examples.en: Could you grab about three croquettes from the butcher shop in the shopping street by the station?
examples.ja: ちょっと駅前の商店街のお肉屋さんでコロッケを３個ほど買ってきてくれない？

meaning_mnemonic:
If there are <kanji>merchandise</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji>s filling the <kanji>streets</kanji>, then you must have wandered into a <vocabulary>shopping district</vocabulary>. Hope you remembered to bring your wallet!

商店街 generally refers to a pedestrian-friendly street or area with lots of local shops and small businesses. Many 商店街 are covered with a roof, in which case they become <vocabulary>shopping arcade</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This main road with a row of trees is my relaxation spot.
examples.ja: この並木街道は私のいこいの場です。

examples.en: If you take this highway straight for a while, you will eventually arrive at Kyoto.
examples.ja: この街道をずっとまっすぐ行くと、そのうち京都に着きますよ。

examples.en: I'm traveling by bike along the highways, visiting various places across Japan.
examples.ja: 僕は街道を自転車で旅して、日本各地を回っています。

examples.en: Tokai-do Road, Nakasen-do Road, Nikko-kaido Road, Koshu-kaido Road, and Oshu-kaido Road are called Gokaido, which were the five principal routes used during the Edo period.
examples.ja: 東海道、中山道、日光街道、甲州街道、奥州街道は、五街道と呼ばれ、江戸時代の五大陸上交通路であった。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>street</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is as wide as a street and a road combined together. So cool! So wide! It must be a <vocabulary>main road</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>highroad</vocabulary>!

Keep in mind 街道 isn't a generic term for main roads. It usually refers to important routes that connect different regions of Japan, especially those from the Edo period, like 日光街道 (Nikkōkaidō) and 中山道 (Nakasendō). But it can also refer to main roads with historical significance in other countries, like アッピア街道 (the Appian Way) in Italy or オックスフォード街道 (Oxford Street) in the UK.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. One thing to note though:

This word uses the かい reading for 街 (not がい). And even when 街道 is a suffix, it never gets rendaku'd! Remember this by imagining every <vocabulary>main road</vocabulary> being full of <reading>kay</reading>aks (かい) for some reason. Just a traffic jam of kayaks up and down the 街道.

examples.en: When the doctor examined me, I was told it was just a cold.
examples.ja: 医者に診てもらったら、ただのカゼだと言われました。

examples.en: My child got injured, so I went to get them checked out right away.
examples.ja: 子供がケガをしたので、すぐに診てもらいに行きました。

examples.en: If these symptoms persist, you should get diagnosed by a doctor soon.
examples.ja: この症状が続くなら、早めにお医者さんに診てもらったほうがいいよ。
