examples.en: I want a doctor to examine my baby to see if she's growing well.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんがちゃんと育っているのか、お医者さんに診てもらいたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: In order to <kanji>diagnose</kanji> a patient, you must first go <vocabulary>to examine a patient</vocabulary>. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is <vocabulary>to examine</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 見る, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading <reading>み</reading>る as well.

examples.en: I'm going to have a medical examination at the hospital today.
examples.ja: 今日は病院で診察を受けます。

examples.en: I asked the doctor various questions during the examination.
examples.ja: 診察中に、医者に色々と質問しました。

examples.en: I wonder how much the doctor's visit will cost.
examples.ja: 診察代、いくらぐらいになるかな？

examples.en: The doctor has a jam-packed medical exam schedule.
examples.ja: 先生は診察の予定がみっちり詰まっています。

meaning_mnemonic:
I will <kanji>diagnose</kanji> you by making an informed <kanji>guess</kanji> during this <vocabulary>medical exam</vocabulary>. 

診察 is what a doctor does when they take a look at you — a <vocabulary>medical examination</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>medical consultation</vocabulary>. Keep in mind this doesn't refer to specific medical tests you might undergo to help the doctor diagnose you. (For those, you'd use 検査.)
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I forcefully stuffed a lot of clothes into the suitcase.
examples.ja: たくさんの服をスーツケースに無理やり詰めました。

examples.en: If you overpack it, the zipper won't close.
examples.ja: あんまり詰めすぎると、ファスナーが閉まらなくなるよ。

examples.en: Excuse me, could you move a bit closer together to make some space for me?
examples.ja: すいません、もう少し詰めてもらえませんか？

examples.en: Can you put some rice in my bento box for me?
examples.ja: お弁当にご飯を詰めといてくれない？

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stuffed</kanji>, this word means <vocabulary>to stuff in</vocabulary>, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know this because you're a <reading>mail</reading> (める) carrier, and you always have to stuff mail into people's packed mailboxes. Why don't these people check their mail more? It’s hard work trying to cram in all this junk mail!

詰める refers to tightly fitting something into an available space, like cramming clothes into a suitcase, putting jam into a jar, or even scooting over to make room, as you're squeezing yourself into a narrower space.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.

examples.en: I desperately needed money, so I borrowed some from a loan shark, but then they demanded an exorbitant sum from me and my situation got even worse.
examples.ja: お金に困ってヤミ金から借りたら、法外な金額が請求されて余計困りました。

examples.en: I'd like to request a cancellation of this bill because I believe the amount on it is incorrect.
examples.ja: 請求書の金額が間違っていると思うので、請求の取り消しをお願いしたいです。

examples.en: I'm told that I can claim a reimbursement later for the parcel's shipping cost.
examples.ja: 荷物の送料は後で請求可能だと言われています。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>request</kanji> then you <kanji>request</kanji> again… Yep, this sounds like a <vocabulary>request</vocabulary to me.

請求 isn't just any old casual request — it's used when formally requesting something from another party. It often involves payment requests (like a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary>), but can also refer to asking for things like application forms or informational materials. It can even refer to the kind of <vocabulary>claim</vocabulary> you file in court.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Undertaking this project is risky, but I want to give this challenge a try.
examples.ja: この案件を請けるのはリスクが高いですが、チャレンジしてみたいです。

examples.en: She often willingly takes on last-minute requests, which is really helpful.
examples.ja: 彼女は急な注文でも快く請けてくれることが多いので、本当に助かっています。

examples.en: I only took this project so that you could save face.
examples.ja: お前の顔を立てるためだけにこのプロジェクトを請けたんだからな。

examples.en: When taking on a job, I first consider whether it's something the employees will be happy to do. If you don't put profits as a secondary concern, you won't be able to deliver quality work.
examples.ja: 仕事を請けるときは、社員が喜んで受ける仕事かを考えて、請けるか決めるんです。売り上げは二の次にしないと、いい仕事はできませんからね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Someone <kanji>request</kanji>s something, and you're the one <vocabulary>to take on</vocabulary> their request. Wow, how nice of you <vocabulary>to accept</vocabulary> that request!

請ける is a formal word often used in business contexts to describe someone willingly accepting a job, task, or request. For example, you might use 請ける when taking on a new project or accepting customer orders.
reading_mnemonic: What's another word for "to accept" or "to receive"? How about 受ける? They share a reading!

examples.en: This isn't mine, it's a rental bike.
examples.ja: これは私のじゃなくて、貸し自転車なんです。

examples.en: I’m living in a rental warehouse now.
examples.ja: 今は貸し倉庫で寝泊まりしているんです。

examples.en: We are planning to spend the coming holidays at a rental cottage.
examples.ja: 今度の休暇は貸し別荘で過ごす予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: To lend or to rent is 貸す. This is the noun version of that, used as a prefix. It is something that has been rented, a "<vocabulary>rental</vocabulary> ____," like a 貸しビル (rental office building) or 貸しボート (rental boat).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 貸す.

examples.en: I’m good at getting lost.
examples.ja: 私は道に迷うのが得意です。

examples.en: It was my first time in the area, so I got lost.
examples.ja: 初めての場所だったので、道に迷ってしまいました。

examples.en: I was looking at the map, but I still ended up getting lost.
examples.ja: 地図を見てたのに、結局道に迷ってしまった。

examples.en: I got lost, but a kind person helped me, and I safely arrived at my destination.
examples.ja: 道に迷ったけど、親切な人に助けてもらって無事に目的地に着きました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 迷う? It means "to get lost." If you get lost on a <kanji>road</kanji>, you are still lost, wandering around looking for the correct turn. This word means <vocabulary>to be lost</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get lost</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the words 道 and 迷う.

examples.en: All of the cabinet ministers are opposed.
examples.ja: 閣僚たちは、みんな反対しています。

examples.en: The cabinet meeting is held once a month.
examples.ja: 閣僚会議は月1回ですよ。

examples.en: An internal whistleblower revealed the communication between the cabinet ministers regarding this issue.
examples.ja: 内部告発者により、この件に関する閣僚間のやりとりが明るみに出ました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>cabinet</kanji> <kanji>colleague</kanji>s are the <vocabulary>cabinet ministers</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cabinet secretaries</vocabulary>. They're the people in the Cabinet who are all colleagues with each other, making them <vocabulary>cabinet members</vocabulary>. Depending on the country, they're also called ministers or secretaries.

閣僚 is a formal term that refers to the collective group of high-ranking officials in a cabinet, but it can sometimes refer to an individual cabinet member as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This was already decided in the cabinet meeting.
examples.ja: これはもう閣議決定されたことです。

examples.en: Did you watch the Digital Minister's press conference after yesterday's cabinet meeting?
examples.ja: 昨日のデジタル相の閣議後の会見、見ましたか？

examples.en: What did we discuss at the cabinet meeting held earlier today? I forgot.
examples.ja: さっきの閣議では何が議題だったんだっけ？忘れちゃった。

examples.en: Most of the cabinet members cast an opposing vote at this cabinet meeting.
examples.ja: 今回の閣議では閣僚のほぼ全員が反対に回った。

meaning_mnemonic: When <kanji>the cabinet</kanji> meets for <kanji>deliberation</kanji> they are having a <vocabulary>cabinet meeting</vocabulary>. So governmenty.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: His actions were truly heroic.
examples.ja: 彼の行動はまさに英雄的だった。

examples.en: I’m pissed off at that guy who only has luck and no real ability, but pretends as if he were a hero.
examples.ja: あいつは運だけで実力もないくせに英雄気取りで本当にムカつく。

examples.en: That soccer player instantly started being treated like a hero after scoring that last goal in the game, huh?
examples.ja: あのサッカー選手、あの試合の最後のゴールで一気に英雄あつかいされるようになったね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've learned 英 means "England," but it can also mean <kanji>excel</kanji>. So what kind of person excels at being <kanji>brave</kanji>? A <vocabulary>hero</vocabulary>!

英雄 is a relatively formal word often used to describe historical or legendary heroes, like William Wallace or King Arthur. In more casual contexts, like when talking about superheroes or referring to your dad as your hero, ヒーロー is more common.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I visited South Korea last year.
examples.ja: 私は去年、韓国を訪れました。

examples.en: I wonder if this Korean drama series will be rebroadcasted.
examples.ja: この韓国ドラマ、再放送されるのかな。

examples.en: In South Korea, there are many Koreans who learn Japanese.
examples.ja: 韓国には日本語を学ぶ韓国人がたくさんいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>Korea</kanji> <kanji>Country</kanji> is <vocabulary>Korea</vocabulary>, of course... well, <vocabulary>South Korea</vocabulary> that is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This custom is frequently seen in both Japan and Korea.
examples.ja: この風習は日韓両国でよく見られます。

examples.en: Learning about the history between Japan and Korea is very important.
examples.ja: 日韓の歴史について学ぶことは、とても重要です。

examples.en: Japan-Korea soccer matches always turn into intense battles.
examples.ja: 日韓のサッカー試合はいつも熱い戦いになります。

examples.en: In 1965, The Japan-Republic of Korea Basic Relations Treaty became in effect.
examples.ja: 1965年に日韓基本条約が締結されました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Take the 日 from 日本 (Japan) and the 韓 from 韓国 (Korea), and stick 'em together to get an abbreviation for <vocabulary>Japan and South Korea</vocabulary>.

日韓 is a bit formal, so you'll usually see it in newspapers or reports referring to Japan and South Korea together. Think international relations and soccer matches.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Satoshi is full of curiosity, isn't he!
examples.ja: サトシ君は好奇心いっぱいですね！

examples.en: These days, I don't experience anything that stimulates my curiosity.
examples.ja: 最近好奇心が刺激されるような経験してないなー。

examples.en: I got soaked on the water slide, and people were looking at me with curious eyes.
examples.ja: ウォータースライダーでびしょびしょにぬれてしまい、他の人から好奇心に満ちた目で見られた。

examples.en: When I was a child I was full of curiosity.
examples.ja: 子どもの頃、私は好奇心旺盛でした。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>like</kanji> it because it gives you an <kanji>odd</kanji> feeling in your <kanji>heart</kanji>. You don't quite know what it is you like, but that's because it's <vocabulary>curiosity</vocabulary> that you have.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's difficult to explain odd numbers to a three-year-old.
examples.ja: 奇数を3才の子どもに説明するのは難しいです。

examples.en: For some reason, I feel like there are more events in odd-numbered months.
examples.ja: 何故か奇数の月はイベントが多い気がします。

examples.en: Because the number of participants is odd, we're one person short for pairing everyone up.
examples.ja: 参加者の数が奇数だから、ペアになってもらうには一人足りないね。

examples.en: Odd numbers are numbers that cannot be divided by two.
examples.ja: 奇数とは2で割り切れない数字のことです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Odd</kanji> <kanji>numbers</kanji> are <vocabulary>odd numbers</vocabulary> (as in, 1, 3, 5, 7, though they are a bit strange as well).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you know the show called "Tales of the Unusual"?
examples.ja: 『世にも奇妙な物語』っていう番組、知ってる？

examples.en: My favorite manga is "JoJo's Bizarre Adventure".
examples.ja: 私の好きなマンガは『ジョジョの奇妙な冒険』です。

examples.en: The distant footsteps carried a peculiar rhythm, which only added to their eerie nature.
examples.ja: 遠くから聞こえてくる足音には、奇妙な規則性があり、それがかえって不気味だった。

meaning_mnemonic:
That's very <kanji>odd</kanji> and <kanji>strange</kanji>, making it <vocabulary>bizarre</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>peculiar</vocabulary>.

奇妙 is often used in literature to describe something that feels unusually <vocabulary>strange</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>odd</vocabulary>. It describes something being an almost otherworldly quality, sparking curiosity because it's so bizarre.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In Kyoto, I bought a beautiful piece of fabric as a souvenir.
examples.ja: 京都で、お土産に美しい織物を買いました。

examples.en: Can we make something out of this woven cloth?
examples.ja: この織物を使って何か作れないかな？

examples.en: This region is famous for its traditional textile production.
examples.ja: この地域は伝統的な織物の生産で有名です。

examples.en: I'm majoring in politics, but somehow I started working for a fabric company.
examples.ja: 政治学が専門なのですが、何故か織物会社に就職しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>weave</kanji> a <kanji>thing</kanji>, you get a <vocabulary>textile</vocabulary>.

織物 primarily refers to woven <vocabulary>fabric</vocabulary>. It's often associated with traditional crafts, such as kimono textiles.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 織 you can pull the reading from 織る. With 物 you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often もの and not ぶつ. Just think of a piece of cloth that is <reading>mono</reading>chrome.

examples.en: "What a heartless thing to say!" said Koichi with anger in his voice.
examples.ja: 「よくそんな冷たいことが言えるよな！」と、コウイチは怒気をおびた声で言った。

examples.en: The other person suddenly grew quiet, perhaps sensing my anger.
examples.ja: 相手は、こちらの怒気を感じたのか、急に静かになった。

examples.en: I tried to hide my anger, but could only manage a strained smile.
examples.ja: なんとか怒気を隠そうとしたが、引きつった笑顔しか作れなかった。

examples.en: His nostrils swelled with anger.
examples.ja: 彼の鼻の穴は怒気を含んで膨らんでいる。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>angry</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> comes out of you when you have <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary>.

怒気 looks simple, but it's a pretty advanced term more commonly used in literature, typically to describe a character's anger as expressed through their voices, facial expressions, attitudes, or the surrounding atmosphere.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm hungry. Can you make something for me?
examples.ja: 腹が減ったなぁ。何か作ってよ。

examples.en: I'm starving! But I already ate my bento.
examples.ja: 腹が減ったよ〜！でもお弁当もう全部食べちゃった。

examples.en: You just ate a little while ago, and you're already hungry again?
examples.ja: さっき食べたばっかなのに、もう腹が減ったの？

examples.en: I’m hungry. Would you like to continue this over lunch?
examples.ja: 腹が減ったな。この件については、昼飯を食べながら話さないか？

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <kanji>belly</kanji> has <kanji>decreased</kanji> in the amount of stuff inside it, you become <vocabulary>hungry</vocabulary>.

腹が減った is a casual way of saying <vocabulary>I'm hungry</vocabulary> in Japanese, often with a bit of a rough or masculine tone.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is 腹 plus 減る put together. With these two combined, you have はらがへった.

In casual speech, you might hear 腹減った without the が more often. The version with が is more common in writing or fixed expressions like 腹が減っては戦ができぬ (you can't fight on an empty stomach).

examples.en: Don't leave the electrical Maneki Neko plugged into the outlet.
examples.ja: 電動招き猫のコンセント、	さしっぱなしにしないでね。

examples.en: We purchased a maneki neko for the Tofugu office to improve WaniKani sales.
examples.ja: もっとワニカニが売れるように、トーフグオフィスに招き猫を買いました。

examples.en: The maneki neko often seen in stores is raising its left paw, since the left hand is believed to "beckon customers."
examples.ja: お店によく置かれている招き猫は、左手を上げています。これは、左手が「お客さんを招く」とされているためです。

examples.en: On the other hand, a maneki neko with its right paw raised is said to "beckon money and good fortune," so they are often displayed in offices or homes.
examples.ja: 一方、右手を上げている招き猫は「お金や幸運を招く」とされているので、オフィスや個人宅にかざられることが多いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>beckoning</kanji> <kanji>cat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>beckoning cat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>maneki neko</vocabulary>. 

招き猫 are the cat statues believed to bring good luck and fortune to their owners. They're often placed in front of shops with one paw raised, as if beckoning and saying, "Hey, come on in!"
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you know already!

examples.en: We will be setting up a shop in Ginza.
examples.ja: 今度、銀座に店を構えることになりました。

examples.en: Try holding the camera with both hands and positioning it diagonally like this.
examples.ja: こんな風に、カメラを両手で持って、ななめに構えてみてください。

examples.en: When you play poker it’s important to prepare patiently.
examples.ja: ポーカーをする時は、気長に構えることが大切です。

examples.en: As both opponents positioned their fists in front of their chests, the starting bell of the match rang out.
examples.ja: 両者が拳を胸の前に構えると、試合開始のゴングが鳴り響いた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>set up</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to set up</vocabulary>, as in establishing something in an orderly manner.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to assume a stance</vocabulary>, like taking a fighting posture, or to hold in preparation, such as a weapon, while preparing to engage in a fight.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is like 構う, so as long as you know that you know this too.

examples.en: It has been three years since I have visited here.
examples.ja: ここを訪れるのは三年ぶりです。

examples.en: This is a picture of my first visit to Rome.
examples.ja: これは、初めてローマを訪れた時の写真です。

examples.en: But then a turning point came.
examples.ja: しかし、そんな時に転機が訪れたんです。

examples.en: If you want to visit the ramen factory you should make your reservations as far in advance as possible.
examples.ja: もしあのラーメン工場に訪れたいのであれば、できるだけ早くに予約を入れる方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>visit</kanji> and the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>.

What makes it different from 訪ねる, though? With 訪ねる, you're going somewhere or visiting someone with a clear purpose. With 訪れる, the emphasis is on the act of visiting a place (and not a person), regardless of purpose. So, if you're simply saying that you're going to go visit the Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto, you could say 訪れる. On the other hand, if you're visiting the Kiyomizu Temple to discover something, or you're going to pay a visit to a teacher in Kyoto for some advice, you could use 訪ねる.

Those uses we just described for 訪れる are for when it is transitive. However, it can also be intransitive, if the action is done by something rather than someone. In that case, it means "to come", as in "winter comes" (冬が訪れる) or "peace comes" (平和が訪れる). 訪ねる, on the other hand, cannot be used in this way.
reading_mnemonic: The reading isn't the same as 訪ねる, though, I'm afraid. It's おとず. Remember how this means just visiting a place? Unfortunately, you completely forgot what you were visiting. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "<reading>Oh Toes</reading>!" (おとず), you exclaim.

examples.en: There's a rumor that he's under police surveillance.
examples.ja: 彼は警察に監視されているというウワサがあります。

examples.en: She quietly slipped away, evading the observant eyes.
examples.ja: 監視の目をかいくぐって、彼女は静かに立ち去ったんです。

examples.en: Do you ever feel like your online activity is being monitored by the government?
examples.ja: 時々、オンラインでのアクティビティが政府に監視されていると感じることはありませんか？

examples.en: I have a surveillance camera, but I haven't checked the tape yet. I wonder if it's working properly.
examples.ja: 監視カメラは持ってるんですが、まだテープを確認した事はないんですよね。ちゃんと撮れてるのかな。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>oversee</kanji> and <kanji>look at</kanji> all that is in your domain. You are conducting <vocabulary>surveillance</vocabulary>.

監視 is the active <vocabulary>observation</vocabulary> of someone or something to ensure safety or compliance, or to detect suspicious activity. It can also refer to the people who carry out this <vocabulary>monitoring</vocabulary>, either directly or through the use of things like cameras.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I supervised a final exam today at work.
examples.ja: 今日は仕事で期末試験を監督しました。

examples.en: The coach's leadership led the team to victory.
examples.ja: 監督のリーダーシップが、チームを優勝に導きました。

examples.en: Michael is comparing movies directed by Hayao Miyazaki to other anime movies.
examples.ja: マイケルは、宮崎はやお監督の映画を他のアニメ映画と比べています。

examples.en: I can't remember the name of that movie director. What was his name?
examples.ja: あの映画監督の名前が思い出せないんだけど。何て名前だっけ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The one who <kanji>oversee</kanji>s and <kanji>direct</kanji>s is the one who gives <vocabulary>supervision</vocabulary>. 

監督 refers to the act of supervising or to the person who supervises, such as the <vocabulary>head coach</vocabulary> of a sports team or a movie <vocabulary>director</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I decided to study abroad in Japan because my teacher encouraged me to do so.
examples.ja: 先生に勧められて、日本に留学することにしたんです。

examples.en: If you know anyone learning Japanese, please recommend Tofugu and WaniKani to them!
examples.ja: 日本語学習者のお知り合いがいたら、ぜひトーフグとワニカニを勧めてくださいね！

examples.en: When I mentioned having chest pains, my coworker recommended that I see a doctor.
examples.ja: 心臓が痛いというと、同僚から医者に受診することを勧められました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recommend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading think about how you are going <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary> this restaurant to your friends, <reading>Sue</reading> and <reading>Sue</reading> (すす). You refer to them as "Sue Sue" to make things easier on yourself, and they're always looking for recommendations.

examples.en: I think solicitation calls are annoying.
examples.ja: 勧誘の電話は迷惑だと思う。

examples.en: Aggressive solicitation is often disliked.
examples.ja: 強引な勧誘は嫌われることが多い。

examples.en: Malicious solicitation is prohibited by law.
examples.ja: 悪質な勧誘は法律で禁止されている。

examples.en: This securities salesman is skilled at soliciting customers for his investment products.
examples.ja: この証券マンは投資商品の勧誘をするのが上手だ。

examples.en: I got a lot of invitations to participate in club activities at the beginning of the university year.
examples.ja: 大学生活の最初は、部活の勧誘をたくさん受けました。

meaning_mnemonic:
I <kanji>recommend</kanji> this to you, so I'd like to <kanji>invite</kanji> you to try it. This is a <vocabulary>solicitation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>invitation</vocabulary>.

勧誘 means soliciting someone to buy a product or service or inviting them to join a group or activity, often in a pushy way. It's commonly used to describe what telemarketers and door-to-door evangelists do, or for students recruiting new members for extracurricular activities.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please don't erase what's on the blackboard yet.
examples.ja: まだ黒板を消さないでください。

examples.en: Who is it that wedged the blackboard eraser between the classroom door and made it fall?
examples.ja: 誰ですか、黒板消しを教室のとびらの間にはさんで落としたのは？

examples.en: At our high school, we've incorporated lessons using electronic blackboards.
examples.ja: うちの高校では、電子黒板を使った授業を取り入れています。

examples.en: We can’t use the blackboard so I’ll bring in a whiteboard.
examples.ja: 黒板が使えないので、ホワイトボードを持参しています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>board</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blackboard</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am currently working as a trainee at the factory.
examples.ja: 私は今、工場で研修生として働いています。

examples.en: What I learned during my time as a trainee has been very useful in my current job.
examples.ja: 研修生の時期に学んだことが、今の仕事にとても役立っています。

examples.en: The new trainees are attending orientation starting today.
examples.ja: 新しい研修生たちが今日からオリエンテーションを受けています。

examples.en: This is the new trainee, Miura.
examples.ja: こちらが、新しい研修生の三浦くんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>研修</vocabulary> is a training or study of some kind. If it's in your current <kanji>life</kanji> (生) that you are doing the training, then you are a <vocabulary>trainee</vocabulary>. This is a lot like how a student is in the status of "study life."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading from 研修 should also help you too.

examples.en: I get one spam mail after another.
examples.ja: 迷惑メールが次から次へと送られてくる。

examples.en: Lately, I've been getting more spam emails, and it’s really annoying.
examples.ja: 最近、迷惑メールが増えて困っています。

examples.en: I get so much junk mail that my inbox fills up quickly.
examples.ja: 迷惑メールが多すぎて、受信ボックスがすぐにいっぱいになるんです。

examples.en: Emails from Koichi are always found in the junk mail folder. I wonder why.
examples.ja: コウイチからのメールはいつも迷惑メールフォルダに入ってしまうんだけどどうしてなんだろう？

meaning_mnemonic: When you have "troublesome" (迷惑) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as <vocabulary>spam</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spam mail</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>junk mail</vocabulary>. On a more technical level it's <vocabulary>unsolicited mail</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 迷惑, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)

examples.en: The Nobel Prize was awarded to them for their contribution to the development of less developed countries.
examples.ja: 後進国の発展に寄与したとして、ノーベル賞が授与された。

examples.en: Did you know that Tofugu is contributing to world peace?
examples.ja: トーフグが世界平和に寄与していることを知っているかい？

examples.en: The Finnish composer Jean Sibelius made a significant contribution to the formation of national identity through his music.
examples.ja: フィンランドの作曲家であるジャン・シベリウス は、音楽を通じて、国民意識の形成に多大な寄与をしました。

examples.en: Businesses that contribute more to the local community tend to receive grants more easily.
examples.ja: 地域への寄与度が高いビジネスの方が、助成金は下りやすいんです。

examples.en: A project manager award was given to Ms. Hattori for her contributions to cost reductions and the shortening of delivery times for goods in the project.
examples.ja: プロジェクトのコスト削減への寄与と納品日数短縮をもたらした服部さんにプロジェクトマネージャー賞が贈られた。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>draw near</kanji> to <kanji>give</kanji> something, you are probably giving a <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>.

寄与 is a very formal word that refers to significant contributions in professional or official settings. It's commonly used in academic or business contexts to highlight how someone's work contributes to the advancement of a field of study or the growth of a company.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If possible, may I ask you for a donation to WaniKani?
examples.ja: もしよろしければワニカニに寄付をお願いできますか。

examples.en: I contribute a little money to my alma mater every year.
examples.ja: 毎年少しだけ、母校へお金を寄付しています。

examples.en: This site is run through donations.
examples.ja: このサイトは、寄付金で運営しているものなんです。

examples.en: Wealthy people make large donations mainly for tax-saving purposes.
examples.ja: 金持ちが多額の寄付をするのは、節税のためだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>draw near</kanji> someone and <kanji>attach</kanji> some stuff to them, you're making a <vocabulary>donation</vocabulary>. They get to keep it, after all. 

寄付 means donating money, goods, or resources, usually for a charitable purpose.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I dozed off during class and the teacher got mad at me.
examples.ja: 授業中に居眠りして先生に怒られた。

examples.en: It seems like they dozed off while driving.
examples.ja: 運転中に居眠りしてたみたいなんだ。

examples.en: I nodded off during work, but no one noticed.
examples.ja: 仕事中に居眠りしてしまったけど、誰にも気づかれなかった。

examples.en: The government is seeking public opinions on measures to prevent members of parliament from falling asleep during meetings.
examples.ja: 国会議員の会議中の居眠り対策について、政府は国民に意見を募っている。

meaning_mnemonic:
Sometimes even though you think you're very much awake and <kanji>alive</kanji>, you can't help fall into a <kanji>sleep</kanji> and start <vocabulary>dozing off</vocabulary>. But you're not dead! You're totally alive, so let's hope no one thinks you're doing anything other than <vocabulary>nodding off</vocabulary>.

居眠り refers to light, unintentional sleep. It often happens when someone is supposed to stay awake but dozes off due to tiredness or boredom, like during a meeting, class, or (heaven forbid) while driving.
reading_mnemonic: This word combines the kun'yomi readings from 居る and 眠る, both of which you've learned, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you provoke Dad, dealing with the aftermath will be a hassle.
examples.ja: 父さんを怒らせると後が面倒よ。

examples.en: I didn't mean to make him angry, but I went a little too far with my words.
examples.ja: 怒らせるつもりはなかったけど、少し言い過ぎてしまいました。

examples.en: I thought I had chosen my words carefully to avoid offending her though…
examples.ja: 怒らせないように、言葉を選んだつもりだったんだけどな…。

examples.en: You made that mild-mannered Kubota angry? What the heck did you say?
examples.ja: あの温厚な久保田さんを怒らせただって？一体何を言ったんだい？

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how you learned that 怒る means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means <vocabulary>to anger someone</vocabulary>.

Verbs ending with an あせる sound (like 怒らせる) often mean that you're causing someone to feel, do, or experience something. So, 怒らせる means you make someone angry. You can remember this because you always make Russell (らせる) angry. No matter what you say, you seem to get on his nerves… you're just constantly angering this Russell guy.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 怒る, so you should know this one too!

examples.en: I'll be waiting by the entryway!
examples.ja: 玄関のところで待ってますね！

examples.en: There's a crack in the foyer’s door, so it needs to be repaired.
examples.ja: 玄関のドアにヒビが入ったので、修理が必要です。

examples.en: He folded his umbrella at the entranceway before stepping into the house.
examples.ja: 彼は玄関で傘をたたんでから、家の中に入りました。

examples.en: Please take off your shoes in the entranceway.
examples.ja: 玄関で靴を脱いでください。

meaning_mnemonic: The most <kanji>mysterious</kanji> thing that's <kanji>connected</kanji> to a house is the <vocabulary>entranceway</vocabulary>. When you're walking into one you never know what's coming next. You just take off your shoes and hope the rest of the house isn't really weird or something. If it is, the <vocabulary>entryway</vocabulary> is then your only way out.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Brown rice is good for your health.
examples.ja: 玄米は体に良い。

examples.en: Brown rice is perfect for meals while on a diet.
examples.ja: 玄米はダイエット中の食事にピッタリです。

examples.en: Brown rice contains a lot of vitamins and minerals.
examples.ja: 玄米にはビタミンやミネラルが多く含まれています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Mysterious</kanji> <kanji>rice</kanji> is <vocabulary>unpolished rice</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>brown rice</vocabulary>. You're used to seeing nice white rice, so seeing rice look any other way is really strange for you.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The biggest problem when you buy <vocabulary>unpolished rice</vocabulary> is the <reading>mic</reading>e (まい)! Mice like to eat and sleep in unpolished rice, so you have to be careful when you buy a bag that you get rid of all the sleeping mice before you try to cook it.

examples.en: When I come home from school I plan on dropping by the library.
examples.ja: 学校の帰りに、図書館に寄るつもりです。

examples.en: Excuse me, could you move over a bit more? (Said when you want someone to scoot over to make space (so that you can sit, etc.))
examples.ja: すいません、もう少し寄ってもらえませんか？

examples.en: Today, I plan to go straight home without stopping anywhere.
examples.ja: 今日は、どこにも寄らずにまっすぐ帰る積もりです。

examples.en: Suddenly, a cat came up to me and sat on my lap.
examples.ja: 突然、一匹の猫が私に寄ってきて、ヒザの上に座りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>draw near</kanji>, so this verb version is <vocabulary>to draw near</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to stop by</vocabulary>, since stopping by a place is like drawing near it briefly, right?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're too shy to <vocabulary>draw near</vocabulary> to people, just learn how to use a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ)! Then people will draw near to YOU to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!

examples.en: If you have doubts, you should think it over a bit more.
examples.ja: 迷いがあるなら、もう少し考えたほうがいいよ。

examples.en: I sensed some hesitation in his words.
examples.ja: 彼の言葉には、少し迷いが感じられました。

examples.en: I managed to get rid of my hesitation.
examples.ja: なんとか迷いを断ち切りました。

examples.en: I had no hesitation about quitting the company.
examples.ja: 会社を辞めることに迷いはありませんでした。

examples.en: She accepted the project without any hesitation.
examples.ja: 彼女は迷いなく、プロジェクトを引き受けた。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how you learned that 迷う means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well, when you feel like you've gone astray or gotten lost, you might act with <vocabulary>hesitation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>indecision</vocabulary>. You suddenly have <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary> about where to go or what to do next.

While 迷う can mean getting lost either physically or mentally, 迷い most often conveys an abstract sense of inner conflict or uncertainty, especially in decision making.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading already when you learned 迷う! Just swap the う for an い.

examples.en: Since searching becomes difficult at night, we plan to temporarily pause and then resume in the early morning.
examples.ja: 夜になると捜索が難しくなるため、いったんストップして早朝から再開する予定です。

examples.en: Recently, drones have been used more frequently for search operations in the mountains.
examples.ja: 最近は、山の中の捜索には、ドローンが使用されることが多くなってきました。

examples.en: The police are continuing their investigation for the missing person.
examples.ja: 警察は行方不明者の捜索活動を続けています。

examples.en: I heard that Kondo-san's daughter hasn't come home for three days, and they've filed a missing person report with the police.
examples.ja: 近藤さんのところの娘さん、もう三日も帰ってきてなくて、警察に捜索願を出したんだって。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>search</kanji> <kanji>search</kanji> is a more intense <vocabulary>search</vocabulary>, like the official <vocabulary>investigation</vocabulary> for a missing person.

捜索 is a formal term often used by authorities or in news reports. It refers to an official search for a missing person or thing, and is commonly used in police investigations, rescue missions, or other organized searches.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'll leave everything about this store to your judgment.
examples.ja: この店のことは全て君の判断に任すよ。

examples.en: I'm happy to be entrusted with a big job, but I'm also a little nervous.
examples.ja: 大きな仕事を任されて、うれしいけど少し不安でもある。

examples.en: I'm Tanaka and I've been assigned as project manager. I look forward to working with you all.
examples.ja: 今回、プロジェクトマネージャーを任されることになった田中です。よろしくお願いします。

meaning_mnemonic:
The meaning of this word is the same as 任せる. Both words are pretty common, but 任す is slightly less common than 任せる.

Here's the mnemonic again, just in case you need a refresher:

If you pass a <kanji>duty</kanji> on to someone, that means you're going <vocabulary>to entrust something</vocabulary> to that person, or you're going <vocabulary>to delegate something</vocabulary>. In other words, you're going <vocabulary>to leave something to</vocabulary> them, so that they do it for you.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the same reading you learned with 任せる.

examples.en: Where can I buy a bus ticket?
examples.ja: バスの乗車券はどこで買える？

examples.en: Do you offer discount tickets?
examples.ja: 割引乗車券はありますか。

examples.en: I was sure I put my train ticket in my inside pocket, but I can't find it.
examples.ja: 電車の乗車券を内ポケットに入れたはずなのに、見当たらないの。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you want to <kanji>ride</kanji> in a <kanji>car</kanji>, the <kanji>ticket</kanji> you'll need is a <vocabulary>passenger ticket</vocabulary>.

乗車券 is primarily a <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary> for a train ride, so think of "car" here as a train car. It can also refer to tickets for other rides, like Ferris wheels, cable cars, ropeways, or certain buses that require a prior ticket purchase.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There aren't many tonkatsu restaurants around here.
examples.ja: この辺は、豚カツ屋が少ない。

examples.en: I think I'll have the breaded pork cutlet set meal.
examples.ja: 豚カツ定食にしようと思います。

examples.en: Ahhh, why did I eat so much tonkatsu yesterday?
examples.ja: あーーー、なんで昨日あんなに豚カツ食べちゃったんだろう。

meaning_mnemonic:
豚 comes from 豚肉 (pork), and カツ comes from the word "cutlet" and means just that. And a <kanji>pork</kanji> カツ is what any Japanese food fan will probably know as simply <vocabulary>tonkatsu</vocabulary>, a.k.a. <vocabulary>breaded pork cutlet</vocabulary>.

豚カツ is a Japanese pork cutlet coated in crispy panko breadcrumbs and deep-fried, making it light and crunchy. It's usually served with a tasty sweet-savory sauce. It's so good, you'll pig out on it!
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the on'yomi of 豚. You haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You really like <vocabulary>tonkatsu</vocabulary> so you just ate a whole <reading>ton</reading> (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of <vocabulary>breaded pork cutlet</vocabulary>.

examples.en: When my mother saw this, she was absolutely furious.
examples.ja: それを見た母は、大激怒でした。

examples.en: He stormed off in a fit of rage.
examples.ja: 彼は激怒してその場を立ち去りました。

examples.en: This movie made significant changes to the original work, which infuriated the fans.
examples.ja: この映画は、原作を改変しすぎて、ファンを激怒させました。

examples.en: Putting one's shoes on a bench may be fine in other countries, but in Japan it would cause indignation.
examples.ja: 土足でベンチに上がるの、海外ならいいかもしれないけど、日本では激怒ものだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Being <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>angry</kanji> means you're filled with <vocabulary>rage</vocabulary>, or for you to <vocabulary>be enraged</vocabulary>.

激怒 is a relatively formal word, often used in literature to describe someone flying into a rage or experiencing intense, uncontrollable anger. Therefore, you’ll frequently encounter this as a suru-verb in the form of 激怒する.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Despite the repeated outpourings of criticism, that YouTuber continued to create content.
examples.ja: あのYouTuberは、相次ぐ批判の声にも負けず、コンテンツを作り続けた。

examples.en: Due to the coronavirus, film screenings were canceled one after another that year.
examples.ja: その年は、コロナのせいで上映中止が相次ぎました。

examples.en: Due to a series of accidents caused by drunk driving nationwide, the police intensified their enforcement.
examples.ja: 飲酒運転による事故が全国で相次いだため、警察は取り締まりを強化しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that happen <kanji>mutual</kanji>ly right <kanji>next</kanji> to each other are said <vocabulary>to happen successively</vocabulary>. In other words, <vocabulary>to happen one after another</vocabulary>.

相次ぐ is a relatively formal word often used in news reports to talk about multiple events or incidents happening one after another, usually in quick succession.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi readings. You've learned this reading for 相, but not for 次. Instead of giving you a mnemonic, we think it's easier to remember that 次ぐ being read つぐ comes from the 次 reading つぎ. Not too hard! All in all, that makes this あいつぐ.

examples.en: Oh no! I'd forgotten to apply for a visa.
examples.ja: しまった！ビザの申請を忘れてた。

examples.en: The application process is taking quite a while to complete.
examples.ja: 申請手続きに時間がかかってるんです。

examples.en: At last, the application for permission has been accepted!
examples.ja: ようやく許可申請が受理されました！

meaning_mnemonic: When you say humbly that you're requesting something, you're putting forward an application. 申請 refers to the process of officially applying for approval or permission, like ビザの申請 (application for a visa), ライセンスの申請 (application for a license), or 休暇の申請 (application for leave/vacation).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You already know this reading for 請, but not for 申, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Today you finally submitted your <vocabulary>application</vocabulary> for a new <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Your old one had to be painstakingly removed after you banged it against a table. Anyway, congrats on the application for your new shin!

examples.en: Staying up late and stress are causes of acne.
examples.ja: 夜更かしやストレスがにきびの原因です。

examples.en: My younger brother's finally gotten into staying up late too — he plays video games until dawn.
examples.ja: うちの弟もついに夜更かしを覚えちゃってさ、夜が明けるまでゲームしてるよ。

examples.en: During the Obon holiday, my dad kept staying up late and my grandma got mad at him.
examples.ja: 私の父は、お盆休み中に夜更かしばかりして、おばあちゃんに怒られてました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 夜更け meant "late at night"? Well, this is similar to that, but instead of referring to the time of night, it refers to the act of <vocabulary>staying up late</vocabulary>. 

夜更かし typically means staying up well past the time you know you should be going to bed. It's often associated with guilty pleasures like binge-watching TV shows or gaming.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the same readings as 夜更け. If you can remember that one, you should be fine here as well!
